campaign.story:
Our Kickstarter campaign has ended, but you can still order your own Cubetto here
THE MOST CROWD-FUNDED EDUCATIONAL INVENTION EVER! $1.59 MILLION!! 6,553 BACKERS!!! THANK YOU!!!!
The journey continues... join us on...
Facebook | Twitter | Press | Say hi!
Cubetto is a coding toy for girls and boys. Powered by a tangible programming language. It's super fun, super intuitive, and we need your help to make it happen!
This is how it works...
As seen on:
Programming without the screen
Children help Cubetto find his way home by writing their first programs using a set of colorful coding blocks.
For girls and boys ages 3 and up
Children can use it even if they can't read yet, so no matter what language they speak, hands-on coding is at their fingertips.
Does it work?
Cubetto combines Montessori learning principles with computer programming concepts. We sold, hand-built, and shipped over 800 early prototypes to educators and parents in over 40 countries to test our assumptions.

Here's what some of them had to say...
Why?
Coding is a basic 21st century literacy, and one our children can't afford to miss out on, but if you made it this far, you already know this!

Starting young gives them an edge, and starting with something fun, that they actually enjoy, means they learn faster and better.
Stretch Goals!
Inside the box
Every Cubetto Playset comes with all the necessary parts to begin play right out of the box:
1. Cubetto 
2. Board 
3. 16 Blocks (4x Forward, 4x Right, 4x Left, 4x Function)
4. 1x1m World Map 
5. Story Book
Cubetto is a wooden robot that wants to be told where to go and how to get there. A smiling companion capable of motoring his way through any adventure.
Think of the Board as an interface or a command line. Use it with the blocks to send instructions to Cubetto. There's one main sequence (A), a subroutine (B), and a Go button (C) to send instructions to Cubetto.
Our blocks are a new, procedural programming language. Much like LOGO was back in the 70's, except you can touch it! Each block is a specific and unambiguous instruction, easy to recognise and combine into a meaningful sequence.
Green - Forward 
Yellow - Left 90º 
Red - Right 90º 
Blue - Function
A floor map drawn on top of a grid helps you plan your next adventure. No destination is too far. Tell a story that means something to you!
Expansion Pack (Now includes all 4 maps!)
New maps, new stories, new adventures. Each one covers an exciting theme and topic, packed with activities and places to visit. Two of each for now, more if we're funded! Each Expansion Pack comes with:
4 World Maps (Solar System, Water World, Ancient Egypt, Cityscapes) 
4 Story Books
50 billion+ ways to play
The most sophisticated of things are often the simplest. There are more than 50 billion sequences you can make with the blocks! No two adventures ever need be the same.
Let toys be toys
Why should coding toys only be for boys and not for girls? Why can't a STEM toy be for both? It can! And it is! 

We want girls and boys to be equally excited about playing and learning with Cubetto. So we’ve designed it based on two universal symbols that are the same for all genders and cultures. A cube, and a smile :)
How is this Montessori?
It's non-prescriptive - Cubetto gives children the ability to solve problems within the world they create. This gives them freedom to express their creativity and aptitudes, unconstrained by the challenges of literacy, or the distractions of a screen.

It's child-centered - All they need to get started is a nudge in understanding that blocks = actions.  After this point, even the discovery of what each block does can be led by the child, leaving adults to observe and only help when needed.

It's auto-didactic - Solving problems with the blocks is about trial and error. Once a sequence is sent to Cubetto, the result is immediate and non-abstract, giving children concrete grounds on which to self-correct without adult intervention. Just change the blocks and go again.

It's designed for scaffolding: When a problem is too complex, the right sequence is easily pooled from collective knowledge of children in the play session. Each child can in turn add a block, or a suggestion, layering in their individual competence to the solution in small steps.
How is this coding?
Algorithms - Algorithms are sets of precise instructions that form a program. Cubetto’s blocks are a physical representation of an unambiguous instruction that children can touch.
The Queue: Instructions in programs are executed following a precise order. On the Board instructions are put together following a wavy line that represents a command line.
Debugging: The instructions are laid on the board, and are immediately executed by Cubetto, so when he doesn't arrive where he should, fixing mistakes is as easy as swapping a block.
Recursions: Create a subroutine by "packing" a sequence in the function line, and call it in the queue with a blue block when you need it. Make long sequences shorted and more elegant, like in the real world.
Infinite Loops: Insert a function block in the function line and watch Cubetto go loopy. Want to stop an infinite loop? hmmm... tried turning it off and on again? :)
Curriculum mapped
We created an online resource centre, packed with curriculum mapped activities and games, to help you get started with Cubetto right away.
We're currently in private Beta, but you can take a look at our teacher's guide. 
Who's using Cubetto?
These are some of the settings where Cubetto is being used to introduce computational thinking, and these are some of the case studies we've collected so far.
Montessori Kindergartens 
Early learning centers 
Elementary schools 
Homeschooling 
Special needs classrooms and inclusion programs 
Afterschool programs 
Technology clubs 
STEM curriculum 
Gifted programs 
Public Libraries and Community Centers 
Maker Spaces 
Tutoring 
Technology camps
Why should 3 year olds learn this?
Much like playing with Cubetto, computational thinking is about breaking down tasks into a logical sequence of steps to reach an objective. In fact, computational thinking is something we do every day to solve all kinds of problems, big and small.
Thinking about the world around us the same way we think in the world of Cubetto is empowering. It gives us the confidence to try things out, break the rules, and shape our environment. Which is pretty amazing!
Playtime with Cubetto is collaborative, because you learn that complicated tasks are best tackled by more than one person. It encourages creativity by showing you there is no right or wrong way to reach your objectives and make the impossible possible.
A game changer for non-sighted children
Cubetto works with shapes, movement and sound. Turning code into something you can touch is changing the way non-sighted, partially sighted and sighted children can now learn the basics of computational thinking in the same setting.
Here’s what leading computer scientist and Code Club chair, Chris Mairs, had to say…
Robots don't change the world, people do!
We're a growing community of over 800 educators, parents and teachers. From Kobe, Japan to Cape Town, South Africa. There's hundreds of us, help us become thousands!
Big things have small beginnings
We came to solve a problem; making coding accessible, tangible and fun for young learners all over the world. It was a shared passion for design, and impending fatherhood that kicked it all off. Here's our story from bean to cup.
March 2013 - In a maker-space far far away... there's a dream
November 2013 - 651 people come together to make it happen!
Jan 2014 - Development begins... lots of it!
2014 to 2015 - Testing... when in doubt ask the experts
April 2015 - The big build! We begin to pack ship and deliver
May 2015 - A Cubetto 2.0 prototype smiles at us through the MoMA Store window
June 2015 - Cubetto 2.0 is complete. Better, smarter, stronger
Feb 2016 - 75 units roll of the factory line for testing. We're ready!
March 8th 2016 - We launch! If successful, it's project timeline
Project timeline
We build with experienced supply chain powerhouse PCH International. PCH were behind the successful delivered of educational products like Kano, Little-Bits along with countless Fortune 500 products all over the world. We're in safe hands, and we're confident of a timely deliver. We've built in sensible buffers to account for any surprises, and all the development is complete.
Tech specs
(A) LEDs, (B) Sequence Line, (C) Function Line, (D) Go Button, (E) Big Screw, (F) Direction Arrow, (G) Battery Housing, (H) On/Off, (I) Shell, (J) Wheels, (K) Castor, (L) On/Off, (M) Battery Housing
Pack Size 27(w) x 26(h) x 15(d)cm, 
Weight (approx.) 1.5kg  
Materials Linden Plywood (varnished), ABS Plastic (matte finish) 
Battery AA x6
Life 4-6hrs (continous play)
Bluetooth BT4.0
Range ≤10m 
Certs FCC IC
Proudly Arduino
The robot is built around the Atmel SAM D21 microcontroller used in the Arduino Zero. It can be easily programmed from the standard Arduino IDE using standard Arduino code. For all intents and purposes, Cubetto's brain is "just" a regular Arduino.

You can update Cubetto from the Arduino IDE. If you want to make your Cubetto do something special, there are thousands of Arduino resources online to help you out. 
Not your cup of tea? Don't worry. You don't need to know anything about electronics to use Cubetto. Just take it out of the box, and begin your adventure right away!
 Why Kickstarter again?
Since November 2013, all our energies and finances have gone into developing a certified, expandable, and durable unit, fit to ship anywhere in the world. Kickstarter allowed us to build and ship a product directly to those who wanted it, building an amazing community in the process, so launching this new version on Kickstarter feels like coming home.
We still need your help!
We're supported by great angels and partners, but there is still a huge part of this equation missing. You! Your backing will allow us to amass enough orders to begin a rolling production. Our first campaign got us this far. Imagine where we could go next?
On the shoulders of turtle
Primo Toys is the effort of many who supported and believed in the project throughout the years. From the MAInD master, where the initial idea for a hands-on coding language was conceived, to the maker spaces, schools and customers who passionately contribute on continuous development.
We're lucky to have built on top of Arduino, an incredible invention, tool, and community that has opened the world of computing education in amazing, groundbreaking ways.
We're also here because of the pioneering work of educators and technologists like Seymour Papert and Jean Piaget (fathers of the Logo programming language) and Maria Montessori, who gave us an amazing framework for development, and some very broad shoulders to stand on indeed.
Ultimately we feel like we're only a small part of a bigger mission, and we hope you will join us on this journey, so that like us, you can become part of something bigger too.
Thank you from all of us at Primo Toys
Filippo Yacob - Founder & CEO
Matteo Loglio - Founder & Interaction Designer
Valeria Leonardi - Number 3 & COO
Ben Callicott - Head of Product
Hugo Mathers - Marketing Assistant
Follow us!
Twitter 
Facebook
Instagram
Writing about us?
press@primotoys.com
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Hardware is hard! The good news is we've done this before. If we're successful, this will be the second Kickstarter project we deliver as a team.

Manufacturing is a complex and exigent process. Things can go wrong, and there will be challenges, big and small. Our pledge is that we will rise to meet each and every one of them, working day and night, doing everything in our power to deliver on our promise.

Our estimates for delivery are conservative, and our partnerships are reliable and solid, but in the event of unexpected issues, we will keep you posted on progress, and vow to work incessantly to minimize impact on delivery.

We will treat every backer as if they were our first, and we promise you a quality product with an honest experience. We hope you choose to join us on this journey.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
The MBelt: put your belt to work
A belt serves two purposes: to hold up your pants and to add style to your outfit. Most belts that attempt to add utility to this equation end up sacrificing style. I have never worn a multi-tool belt before because I take pride in my fashion. I don't want a bulky belt that looks like it belongs on Batman, nor do I want a more fashionable multi-tool belt that I need to take off my waist to actually use. That diminishes the convenience.
What I want is simple. A belt that doesn't try too hard; that I can wear to work; that I can use when I need it and forget about when I don't.
We designed our belt based on a few key principles: 
With these principles, we were able to design a sleek and timeless belt that will seem nothing different than a normal belt until you need it. The price is set at $59 and includes a lifetime guarantee. If anything happens to the buckle, the strap, or the tools, we'll replace them. You shouldn't have to deal with the inconvenience of broken product. That is why we use quality tools, including the Spyderco™ HoneyBee SS knife.
The two portions of the MBelt buckle are held together by two magnets - one of the belt side of the buckle, and one on the tool side (I point out the magnets in the video). The magnets hold it together very firmly, so you won't have to worry about it coming apart by accident.
PLAY

Calvin Klein is widely considered fashionable and forward in their belt design, and their belts were used as inspiration in the MBelt's design. Compare the MBelt to the Calvin Klein belt above. Both are fashionable. Both will work with your outfit. But one is decidedly more convenient.
The MBelt is less than 8mm thick
When people think of a real life utility belt, they usually think of an embarrassingly ugly contraption that a person can "technically" wear in public, but no one that values their appearance would ever be caught wearing one. This is not that. The MBelt is less than 8mm thick and is designed to mimic a standard, timeless belt. 
Buckle + Belt weighs about 250g with the tools included
The MBelt weighs only 250 grams - a similar Calvin Klein belt weights just under 200 grams. Comfort is incredibly important and our #1 priority. 
Powerful neodynium magnets hold the belt together
The MBelt is held together by neodymium magnets and will not come apart unless you want it to. The tools inside are securely magnetically fastened so that they do not rattle. The construction will be backed by a lifetime warranty - if the belt breaks, send it to us and we'll replace it for free. And since the magnets are encased within the metal housing, they will not cause unwanted interference.
The tools secure snugly into place, ready for use.
Knife, bottle opener, and four screwdrivers are included
The MBelt is designed to be used without removing or even undoing the belt. With it's patent-pending front-cover design, simply pop off the cover when you need it and pick the tool you need.
The included tools:
Spyderco HoneyBee SS Knife
Bottle Opener
Phillips PH1
Phillips PH00
Flathead Slotted 4mm
Flathead Slotted 2mm
The screwdriver is driven by the cap. Place the desired screwdriver bit in the hex slot to secure it
Need to tighten a screw? Need a quick prybar? Your office chair coming loose? Four precision screwdriver bits are fitted inside the belt to tackle any small or medium sized job. It will be tough to find a screwdriver more convenient than this.
The cap serves as a bottle opener without removing the tools
At a party and need a quick bottle opener? Pop the cap off the belt and open that bottle up. Works fine with all the tools still in place.
Spyderco™ HoneyBee SS Folding Knife
To most, the knife is the most important tool. We understand this and partnered with the Colorado-based knife company Spyderco™. Spyderco™ is a renowned knife innovator and manufacturer known worldwide for the quality of their products. The Spyderco™ HoneyBee SS  was our knife of choice. In most everyday situations this knife will be more than enough.
Though not the biggest knife in the world, the Spyderco™ HoneyBee SS will be more than enough in most any everyday situation
Pledge $1
Every dollar counts! Get a virtual high five for helping out. 
Pledge $5
I'll send you a personal email with a terrible joke I make up on the spot.
Pledge $39
You'll receive the MBelt buckle (minus the belt strap).
Pledge $59
You'll receive the MBelt buckle with a leather belt strap in black or brown (your choice).
Pledge $99
You'll receive TWO MBelt buckles with leather belts, one black and one brown.
Pledge $199
You'll receive TWO MBelt buckles with beautiful hand stained full grain leather belts, one black and one brown. Each of the belts straps will be branded on the inside with your name (or anything else you want to say, up to 20 characters).
Contact us! Direct inquiries to rich@mbelt.co
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Patent Pending. Application Number 62/127,764.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The process has been set up to minimize potential risk. All parts are bought from external manufacturers, with the knife, screwdriver bits, and belt strap coming off-the-shelf. The only novel part of the design is the buckle casing itself, which can be produced easily using a mold. The only potential hiccup we could face at this point is sub-par quality molds. If this happens, we will have the molds refinished and reworked until we achieve our desired quality.

Our manufacturer has been responsive and on time. The vast majority of our funding will go towards purchasing the molds for mass production. We did our best to front-load DFMEA and PFMEA work to ensure a smooth launch.

Fulfillment should run smoothly as mass distribution will be handled by a fulfillment service. Initial smaller-scale distribution will be completed by our team and when we can no longer handle it we will move to a local fulfillment service.

As the MBelt is managed mostly by Rich Ozdowy, the founder himself, it is possible that the activities become too overwhelming for one dedicated person. At this point additional support will be brought on-board to help make sure this does not become a limitation.

If there are any delays or unforeseen issues (we hope there are none, but it would be foolish to promise everything will run perfectly), we will post updates on our Kickstarter page promptly and do everything we can to keep you updated. Our backers are incredibly important to us; if it wasn't for you, our product would not be a reality. We'll do everything we can to take care of those that believed in us.

Thank you so much for your support!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: If you haven't received your MBelt
updates.update_content:
Dear all backers,
I sincerely apologize for the delay since my last update. The quality issues along with some unexpected personal issues have caused fulfillment of the improved MBelts to run behind schedule. However, I can happily say that we have an updated schedule to ship all the improved MBelts, including replacing anyone's belt strap that was too short.
The schedule is as follows:

updates.update_userinfo: Yes, we are still working on shipping
updates.update_content:
It's been too long since our last update, and I first and foremost want to apologize for that. Communication is key in these campaigns, and we understand we have definite room for improvement and learning here.
That said, we have been working on improving the adhesion of the magnets and have found a good solution. Instead of using JB Weld, we will now be using Gorilla Glue Epoxy after cleaning all surfaces with denatured alcohol.

A large portion of MBelts have been shipped, and we have been receiving some consistent feedback. The general consensus is people love the design, but there are a few key quality concerns, namely:
The magnets come unstuck from the buckle
The Chicago screw that holds the buckle to the belt is a bit weak and can snap
We really appreciate those of you that provided the feedback, and we will continue to work to fix the issues. We are working on improving the magnet adhesion and have ordered stronger Chicago screws. To those of you that have already received your MBelt, you will receive another improved buckle and a new Chicago screw set.

All of the components are here, and we are ready to go! 
If any of your information has changed since previously confirming your address, waist size, and belt color, please shoot me an email at rich@mbelt.co. I know a couple of you have already reached out to me with changes. I'll also err on the side of caution and contact you if your information wasn't confirmed or if anything is ambiguous.

We missed our October ship date. We thought we could be different; we thought we could be the exception to the rule that "all Kickstarters ship late". But here we are, and we are sorry we weren't able to meet the initial timing. To try to make it up to you, we have a few Spyderco Delica knives that will be included in about 10 orders (wish we could include it with everyone's order, but we only have so many to give).
As some background, it has taken longer than we expected for the supplier to make the initial buckle pieces on the production mold. They finished casting all of the parts last week and are now finishing plating, polishing, and brushing.

Hey everyone!
We are so close to shipping out your MBelts. The only thing we are still waiting on is the shipment of the metal buckles from our manufacturer. We solved the previous issues by modifying the mold slightly.
Also, in the pictures below you'll see the MBelts are very shiny, polished metal. The production MBelts will have a brushed nickel finish like in Kickstarter pictures.

Hey Everyone!
Seems like a good time for another progress update.
We received the Spyderco knives in the mail and, as expected, they look fantastic.

Hey everyone!
Great news, I received word over the weekend that the mold has been completed, so I will be receiving samples from it very soon to confirm everything is to specification.
Here are a couple of pictures of the initial sample coming straight off the mold (the pin has yet to be CNC'd and the electro-plating still needs to be applied).

campaign.story:
This project is successfully funded! Head on over to our website to check out what we are up to now and order your own Root Dice.
 What are the Root Dice?
A set of six handmade wooden dice.
Made from bog woods that have been preserved underground for thousands of years.
A slim handmade case in oiled canvas and leather.
A unique numbering system that allows you to roll anything from a D4 to a D20 using six-sided dice.
What is the Archetype Expansion?
Complete Root Dice sets themed to match your character or design preference.
Two of the six dice from the standard set are replaced with themed wood.
The case color, stitching, and leather inlay are themed as well.
6 sets: The Warrior, The Cleric, The Rogue, The Pyro, The Marksman, and The Necromancer.
How do your roll for 20 with six sided dice?
You can get a full explanation of how the root dice system works in the video below, or on this page.
  The Archetypes
The Warrior
The warrior set is made with heavy ironwood and comes in a brown case. Highlighting the rugged features of the warrior class.
The Rogue
The Rogue set comes in a blue/grey case and uses purpleheart for its themed dice. Hinting at the mystery and charm of the thief.
The Pyro
Firey paduk, red canvas, and orange stitching capture the chaotic persona of the fire mage.
The Marksman
Birdseye maple and green canvas help your ranged class dial in the perfect shot.
The Necromancer
If we could have made it darker, we would have. Black palm and the darkest of cases - what else for a master of the black arts?
The Cleric
Bright douglas fir in gold case show off the white magic and protective instincts of your cleric.
Gallery
We are a Chicago-based team of two former game developers turned artisans. We want to create objects that bring back the memories we've made playing the games we love, while also connecting with our adult design aesthetic.
We still cherish the memory of finding out that Samus was a girl, our first purple item in Azeroth, or the clutch roll that saved our favorite rogue. But we've had a hard time finding quality art that represented not only our deep seated fandom, but also reflected our age and design sense. We want to create objects that you can be proud to display in your home or office and use every day. To us, that means capturing the heart and soul of these games and inserting that into our work, while remaining true to our personal tastes. We’re here to provide you with one-of-a-kind, handmade goods that you don’t have to spend 500 rupees on.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We have a strong plan in place to produce dice well beyond what it will take to fulfill rewards for our project goal. While procuring rare woods can sometimes be a challenge, we have located suppliers with huge stocks, and a set of dice doesn't require too much wood.

Our biggest challenges will be managing the complexity of all the available options to backers. We have found some great technology to help us pull that off, so we don't anticipate any delays.

If something unforeseen comes up, you can count on us to communicate clearly and often about what happened and how it is impacting the project. We are here to develop a long-term connection with our backers, and build World Nine into something great. The foundation for that is trust.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Diaspora:
a scattered population with a common origin.
AP Studio Art at Portfolio Day in Chicago
What happens to the energy that ripples away from us in our best moments? My finest moments were spent holding an art class enthralled. 
From my former student Candice:
"Once upon a time, when I was an awkward teen with terrible bangs, a sparkly purse, and a Tool t-shirt, I took a photo class at Maine East. Brandi Martin was my teacher. She was everything all of my other teachers were not: Accessible. Real. Honest. Relatable. She treated us like we were people already. Fast forward to now: thanks to social media we reconnected a few years ago and she is the big sister I never had. 
One day in class, she was demonstrating how to adjust darkroom enlargers and said "If you turn the knob this way, it will unscrew and this whole very expensive piece will come crashing down..." She looked up with a dramatic pause, met each of our eyes to make sure we were looking at her and paying attention. "...do not turn the knob this way." She raised her eyebrows at us and paused again, let it sink in, and it did. Do not turn the goddamn knob this way, people. I would not. Ever. "Turn it this way instead. You will feel it make these very satisfying little clicks."It was a 20 second snippet of my life 13 years ago, and I remember that exchange. The exaggerated way she paused and made sure we were watching, the "satisfying little clicks" was the perfect description of what we were supposed to feel for. As a parent, I have employed that strategy many many times. The quiet. The big pause. The opposite of shouting, but so, so much more effective.
That's a little piece of Brandi that I carry into the world with me. It's a little piece of my teacher that my kids go into the world having experienced. There are over 9000 of us that spent a semester or an entire 4 years with her. Some of us became artists or photographers, but the vast majority of us did not. Yet we still carry these little pieces of her, of all of our teachers, out in the world with us.
So where are the 9,000 now? What are they doing? The pieces of Brandi making art, raising children, making sandwiches, nursing sick people, building roads, building stock portfolios. They are standing in waiting rooms, sitting in church, yelling in traffic, resting in an urn, laying on a beach.
Please consider funding this incredible art project, building a portrait of these pieces who have been scattered around the world over the last two decades."
Rebecca plays with her 3 year old daughter in their back yard. Rebecca made the tutu for her earlier that day, in anticipation of my visit.
There's no standardized test to measure lifelong educational influence. This requires the hard way, locating and visiting 20-30 former students, talking to them about their lives, and what art now means in their daily lives. After taking it all in, I'll make a meaningful portrait about them and their world.  
Keenan looks for a good shot in the Aurora Illinois train station. He's saving money to move to Colorado.
I've already begun tracking down former students, talking to them about the project. I tested the waters by creating a Facebook group. It already grew to 213 members! I asked them to make a video stating their name, age, location, major life activity, and what class they took with me, and got more than I bargained for. I spliced some of the results together to create the video above. These aren't even all of the replies; so many asked me visit and document them! I was deeply moved when Nick actually wrote a song about what he remembered from photo class.
Minha's family is packing up the house to go care for a sick relative in Pakistan. She might go with them to attend med school.
The final product will be a gallery show in Brooklyn next summer (location TBA) that speaks to the humanity of these wonderful people, and to the best kind of student/teacher relationships. I plan on capturing testimony about how the memories of teachers and students continue to influence the quality of each others' lives.
You can help make this happen with your contribution. Your contribution will enable me to travel around the US and for some photo equipment. Any funds that exceed the total will be put towards additional travel to Europe, Brazil, and Japan, where even more of my Diaspora awaits!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
They really do want me to come. I imagine one problem might be that some former students may change their minds about being included in the project. That simply means I have to document more than I need. There is no shortage.

I have most of the equipment I need, but my camera is a bit slow, so I'd like to add a faster DSLR to my camera bag.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

These portraits will live in an ongoing tumblr to serve as a permanent home for their images and stories with links to their projects and accomplishments.

Photographed Candice. A black ball gown, a sun faded couch covered in pine needles, a new tattoo, and an arm brace from a car crashed earlier on her way to pick me up from the airport. Never a dull moment. In addition, I met her brother Ryan, a very talented musician, and we worked out some music and sounds for a soundtrack to the video.

campaign.story:
The Legend of Uncle Louie Sauce
Our tale begins during a high stakes poker game in New Orleans in 1929. Our infamous Uncle Louie, with a "kings over full house", was the big winner. One of the participants was a local New Orleans chef of great renown. Being unable to cover his wager, the chef offered the recipe for his famous sauce as his substitute for hard cash. Every year thereafter, Uncle Louie would secretly concoct his brew and distribute it during the holidays to family and very special friends. We now carry on Uncle Louie’s tradition. We hope you enjoy it as much as we do, for never does a pulled pork, grilled chicken, hamburger, steak or rib pass our lips without this delightfully zesty and unique sauce.
Family pig roast
 A Sauce that Works with Everything
Uncle Louie Sauce is as versatile as it is tasty. Whether you're basting on grilled chicken or hamburgers, marinating a London broil or shrimp, using it as a finishing sauce on top of pulled pork sandwiches, or even spicing up your Sunday morning Bloody Mary, Uncle Louie Sauce will elevate your flavors with its blend of spices.
Meet the Family
Uncle Louie was born in Olevano sul Tusciano, Italy (near Napoli) and emigrated to New York City, eventually settling in Delaware. He was the second-oldest of seven children. Dea's grandfather was the youngest of the seven.
Dea  grew up with the Uncle Louie tradition, and introduced John to Uncle Louie Sauce when they started dating. John's response to the experience of a family pig roast: "If she doesn't marry me, someone at that table will."
The whole family is involved in bringing Uncle Louie Sauce to market. Dea is the master chef. John is in charge of sales. Michael develops and manages the website UncleLouieFoods.com. Kevin is the graphic designer and marketing manager. And Joe is the social media director. Our hope is to introduce Uncle Louie Sauce to food lovers coast to coast.
We Invite You to Join our Family
Last summer we decided to extend the Louie tradition beyond our immediate family and friends. The response has been terrific, so well in fact that we are having trouble keeping up with demand. We are looking for your assistance in expanding our production capacity. We want to grow the Uncle Louie family in kitchens and backyards all across the country and the world.
We truly appreciate your time and contributions!
Learn more about Uncle Louie Sauce at www.UncleLouieFoods.com and www.facebook.com/UncleLouieFoods 
Check out some of the Rewards:
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We have been in commercial production of Uncle Louie Sauce since July 2013. As a result, the risk of not being able to provide our supporters with their bottles of sauce is extremely low (almost negligible). There is always some risk associated with the supply of the other rewards, such as the shirts and other custom products. However, worst case is a slight delay in delivery and we guarantee we will keep an open line of communication with our backers if those delays occur.

campaign.story:
The Root Dice
Six handmade wooden dice.
Bog woods that have been preserved underground for thousands of years.
A slim handmade case in oiled canvas and leather.
Roll anything from a D4 to a D20 using six sided dice with our unique numbering system. 
If you'd prefer, you can get a set of six D6 dice instead. D6 sets come with two dice in each wood.
Bog Woods
Bog woods are a result of a tree falling and then being quickly buried or submerged in water. If everything goes just right, they can be preserved underground for an incredibly long time. Most of these types of woods are found with an entire buried forest so they have developed unique names and histories. We’re using three different types of bog woods for the Root Dice.
Ancient Kauri
Ancient Kauri represents the oldest workable wood on the planet. About 50,000 years ago in New Zealand a major natural event (probably a tsunami) knocked over and buried a huge forest of these trees that had already been growing from some 2,000 years.
Bog Oak
Our Bog Oak was born at the end of the last ice age. Huge oak forests throughout Europe flooded, and the trees died standing and fell into the muck. The swampy conditions have not only preserved these trees, but have turned the wood a deep black color. The bog oak we use is 5,000 years old..
Sinker Cypress
The Sinker Cypress is a product of the logging companies that used America’s rivers as shipping lanes before the Industrial Revolution. As workers were driving these logs downstream to be milled into lumber, some of them would get stuck and sink into the murky river bottom. Now, over 100 years later, they are reclaimed, still showing the beautiful hues of green that cypress is known for.
The System
We came up with a way to roll anything from a D4 to a D20 (and maybe even higher) using a set of six, cube-shaped dice. Each set comes in a slim, handmade case that includes a card explaining the system. Here's the dice in the set:     
2 x D6 in Ancient Kauri
These are standard six-sided dice, with the sixth face replaced with a Root Dice logo.   
1 x Modified Fudge in Bog Oak
Fudge dice usually have 2 plus symbols, 2 minus symbols, and 2 zeros. We have added a plus to one of our zero faces and a minus to the other. This allows the die to be used as a 50/50 coin flip as well, which is needed to accomplish some of our rolls in the full set.
1 x "Fours" in Sinker Cypress
This die has the values 1,2,3,4 and two Root Dice logos. It is used in D4 and D8 rolls. 
1 x "Fives" in Sinker Cypress
This die has faces that are multiples of 5, starting with 0, and two Root Dice logos. Its primary purpose is D20 rolls, but it also pairs nicely with the one of the D6s to make a 20 unit counter. 
 1 x "Tens" in Sinker Cypress 
This dice has multiples of 10, from 10-50, and a Root Dice logo. It is primarily used as a counter to round out the set.
The Root Dice come in a slim handmade case. Oiled canvas with leather accent and elastic closure.
Sample Rolls
We've already found ways to reproduce the most prominent rolls in gaming using these dice in combination, and we're excited to see what else the gaming community will come up with once we get them in your hands. Here's a few examples of how to roll the basics:  
D20 Roll: Grab a D6 and the Fives die. Roll them, and re-roll any dice that show a Root Dice logo. Add them together.   
Simple process right? Here's the math. When you re-roll any logos, you reduce the possible outcomes for the D6 to 1 through 5 and the Fives die to either 0,5,10, or 15. So you have a 1/5 probability and a 1/4 probability for each outcome. Multiply those and you get 1/20, so there are exactly 20 possible outcomes. You end up with same probabilities as rolling a 20 sided die.  
D8 Roll: We'll start by rolling the Modified Fudge and the Fours dice. Once again, re-roll any logos. If the fudge has a + sign showing, add 4 to the Fours die. If not, just use the face value. 
There’s only 4 outcomes on the Fours die, and 2 outcomes on the modified fudge. So the probabilities are 1/2 and 1/4. Multiply those, and you have a 1/8 chance for each number. 
Refer to the FAQ for info on other rolls such as D4, D5, and D12.
We are a Chicago based team of two former game developers turned artisans. We want to create objects that bring back the memories we've made playing the games we love, while also connecting with our adult design aesthetic. 
We still cherish the memory of finding out that Samus was a girl, our first purple item in Azeroth, or the clutch roll that saved our favorite rogue. But we've had a hard time finding quality art that represented not only our deep seated fandom, but also reflected our age and design sense. We want to create objects that you can be proud to display in your home or office and use every day. To us, that means capturing the heart and soul of these games and inserting that into our work, while remaining true to our personal tastes. We’re here to provide you with one-of-a-kind, handmade goods that you don’t have to spend 500 rupees on.
We're getting started with the Root Dice, but eventually we want to make products that fit with all of gaming culture. We hope you'll join us in that mission by supporting this project and coming along for the ride.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We have a strong plan in place to produce dice well beyond what it will take to fulfill rewards for our project goal. While procuring bog wood can sometimes be a challenge, we have located suppliers with huge stocks, and a set of dice doesn't require too much wood.

Our biggest challenges will be consistency as we scale up to produce these larger quantities. Our current tools aren't really up to the job of producing hundreds of sets, but the tools we need to nail it are built into our goal. 

If something unforeseen comes up, you can count on us to communicate clearly and often about what happened and how it is impacting the project. We are here to develop a long-term connection with our backers, and build World Nine into something great. The foundation for that is trust.

With any type of dice that has poor contrast, I have found that judicious application of white out can easily highlight even the most subdued of numbering. The excess can easily be wiped away, leaving well highlighted numerals. I originally got this tip from a USAF armorer, it works well on metal and plastic, I have never tried it on wood but it produces exceptional, professional looking results.

campaign.story:
I'm an outdoorsman at heart, I love hiking around the forests, finding a remote place to camp and spending some quality time in the great outdoors. If there's water, you can bet I'll be in a canoe. And I always try and get some fishing in, no matter where or when. But when you're hiking, camping, canoeing, or any combination of the above, adding tackle and poles can be a difficult prospect. The equipment takes up room, adds weight to your gear, and is cumbersome to use "on the go." You have to unpack everything, assemble it, get some fishing in, then disassemble and repack it all when you're done.

I've always been a fan of fishing without a traditional pole and gear, utilizing other methods such as film-canister survival kits, wrapping line around a water bottle, or simply using a line and a hook. I wouldn't have to worry about the logistics of packing and transporting everything, and I avoided spending tons of money on exotic lightweight materials. But what I really wanted was an ultralight kit that I could carry in my pocket. It had to be easy to deploy, fun and easy to use, reliable, and above all it had to be self-contained with both line and tackle. After some research, development, and testing, the "Pocket Reel" was born. 
Early test models of the pocket reel. These test kits are made from thin walled plastic tubes. The final product uses a different tube, which is roughly the same size but twice as thick as the test model and virtually indestructible.
Final product in the new tube. The original nylon thread from the test models and video has been replaced with a plastic spool holding an additional 45ft of 12lb big game fishing line. endcaps have been changed to blue. Lure color will vary.
The Final kit will contain;
45' 12lb fishing line on the kit
4x #8 fishing hooks
4x 3/0 removable sinkers
10x synthetic maggots 
1x 3/4" bobber
2x spinner lures
1x 45' spool of 12lb big game fishing line
Knot guide with directions
**UPGRADE 1x Crappie/Panfish jig (see update 4 for pics)
PLAY


How I got the idea
I already had experience with a film canister fishing kit in the past. While I liked the concept, in actuality the kit was flawed in just about every way. The canister was too small, so holding onto it while casting proved to be difficult. The canister was too flimsy, so if I landed a fish (even a small one) the canister was almost sure to buckle while pulling it to shore. Lastly, the canister would get knocked around in my pack and open up, and removing hooks from various items got old quick. But it was a starting point.  

I went for something similar in shape but a little bigger, and found an old prescription pill container. I figured the childproof cap could stay on inside my pack, and the tube was pretty strong, so I didn't have to worry about it buckling when I had a fish on the line. But it was still too small and difficult to hold onto, so I started looking for something better.    

I searched my garage, the internet, and various hardware stores in my attempts to find anything tubular that could possibly meet my criteria, and soon ended up with a large stash of containers of varying shapes, sizes, and materials. After testing, one container stood out from the rest, completely surpassing both the film canister and prescription bottle in every aspect. It was large enough to grip comfortably, but small enough to fit into my pocket. It was virtually indestructible, I could probably run over it with a truck and not break it. And lastly, perhaps best of all, the screw cap meant no more fishing hooks everywhere.
Production
Now that I had my container, I moved on to the next problem. The polymer construction of the tube, while strong, meant it had nothing to allow the line to gain traction. Without traction, there'd be no way to reel in a fish. I solved this problem by adding a section of rubber to the end of the tube, providing the line with traction and allowing the user to reel in their catch. With that settled, I stuffed the inside with some hooks, sinkers, synthetic maggots, a 3/4" bobber, a couple spinner lures, and a bobbin of 12lb monofilament fishing line. Finally, for casting, I drilled a hole in the cap and added a lanyard and bead. The kit was ready for trials.

  early concept tackle and kit contents. Note: Since testing, the spool of thread here has been replaced by a spool of additional fishing line
The bead at the top of the kit is used to tighten the lanyard. This prevents the lanyard from slipping off of your wrist.
You will have your choice between either a "Skull" or "Smooth" bead. SKULL beads will be available in either WHITE or PINK. SMOOTH beads will be available in; WHITE, RED, BLACK, or PINK.
Testing the Pocket Reel
I tested it on a fishing trip with four friends. They all had poles and large tackle boxes; I had my fishing kit in the cargo pocket of my pants. When I took it out and showed it around, I was immediately laughed at (good friends, right?). They said, “There’s no way you’re going to catch anything with that.” 
I started off with a baited hook. I set up my line and cast her off, reeled her back in, recast, saw the tell-tale ripples around the bobber, saw it dip underneath the water, got excited and started to reel in the line. The bait was gone. I forgot to set the hook! I recast my line with fresh bait, saw ripples and the bobber went under. I pulled up on the line, set the hook, and reeled in my first catch of the day. 
It was a tiny bluegill—hardly a meal—but more importantly, the kit worked and I was the first one with a fish on. 
I got the nod of approval from my friends and one of them suggested I try a spinner lure. I reset my line with a spinner. The idea with this type of lure is to cast, reel in, and recast to the same area. The line needs to be reeled in with some speed in order to get the spinner to flash underwater. Seemed kind of hard to do without a reel. Boy, was I wrong. Holding the line and moving the kit in a circle with your other hand, the same motion you make when you operate a fishing reel, brought the line in as fast as any rod setup I’ve ever used. With a few practice casts I was able to hit the same spot with my spinner lure. 
Reeling end of the test model.
On the fifth cast, I starting feeling the tell-tale nibble on the lure as it was coming in. The next cast, I landed a small bass, much larger than the bluegill from before. The kit worked wonderfully and it was a lot of fun to use. 
First bass!
I was impressed. My friends were, too. So much so that one of them offered to buy my second spare kit on the spot. It was my first sale. The "Pocket Reel" weighs in at a 3.25oz. fully loaded so it’s very comfortable to carry. I added a knot guide and simple use directions with the kit so anyone can pick it up and fish anytime and anywhere.  
Knot guide and directions that are included in the Pocket Reel
Directions for Use 
You simply pull out your favorite tackle from the kit, remove the elastic band covering the line, and tie on your lure. Slip your hand into the lanyard at the end, put your thumb on the line, and motion your arm like you are skipping a stone across a lake. When your hand is extended, release your thumb and the line will cast. You can do short casts by releasing your thumb and when the line is out as far as you like, point the kit upwards and the line will stop. 
 Website 
Some of the funds raised through kickstarter will help to fund the building of a website and store to sell the Pocket Reel and Accessories. 
Accessories 
Some accessories that will be made available through the website will be.
Spare spools of fishing line
Extra hooks and sinkers
Additional bags of bait.
 Future Ideas for Accessories/Stretch Goals
Hook and Sinker containers that will fit inside the storage compartment of the pocket reel.
  An assortment of lures and tackle to upgrade your kit
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The biggest challenge will be working with new suppliers to obtain the materials needed to build the kits.

Suppliers have already been lined up but we always face the risk of an item being out of stock or backordered. We will work with our suppliers to keep a steady stream of materials flowing into production and will always be actively seeking new suppliers of raw materials.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
I've been involved in music since I was a little tyke, singing in church with my family. I started playing guitar and writing music in college and enjoyed the occasional open mic night. Over the past year, playing music has really taken off for me. I began playing last summer every Saturday morning at a local Farmer's Market. This gave me a fairly wide swath of exposure, and I have been playing gigs almost every weekend since.
I have also written more songs in the past year than in the previous 5 years combined. The next logical step is to record an album.
The Album
My plan is to release an album that has 10-12 tracks. I hope to include mainly songs that were written in the past two years. As I get deeper into the recording process, I will certainly have a better idea of what songs to include. The following songs were written in 2013 and 2014 and may appear on the album (click on the highlighted songs to listen to a rough cut):
Inside My Head
I Will Survive
Lucky Man
Pinpoints of Light
Aleksander
Midwinter
Via Champlain
Makes You Tremble
The Legion of Doom
The NSA Will Never Hear This Song  
Where The Money Will Go
My garage is large enough to fit 4 cars in it. So in one corner of my garage I will build a finished 13x13 room for use as a functional recording studio. This room will be carpeted, insulated and heated. It will be treated with sound dampening foam (not cheap). I will also need to purchase a few pieces of furniture for the studio.
I already have most of the equipment I need, but will need to buy:
professional studio monitors
monitor stands
high quality studio headphones
new microphones
a used drum set
For making the actual album, I will need funds for mastering and pressing the CD. Funds will go to artist Craig Griffin and RoofTopHowl Studio for designing the album, posters and t-shirts and for materials. Shipping costs are also included in the funding goal.
"Why not go record in a professional studio?"  Most of my songs I would not consider "studio ready," meaning that I still need to work out intros, outros, solo parts, instrumentation, etc.  These are things you don't want to do when you're paying a studio by the hour.  Having my own space will allow me to spend time with each song and make creative decisions without being under the pressure of a clock.
A Studio for the Community
After the studio is built and ready to go, I will be able to offer affordable recording sessions to local musicians and community members.  Profits from these sessions would go mainly toward increasing the quality of the studio.
Kickstarter Updates
Part of the Kickstarter model is that contributors receive periodic updates as the project progresses. I will keep you up to speed as the studio gets built and the album gets recorded. Your contribution basically gets you behind the scenes for this process.
Conclusion
The end product of this Kickstarter project will be a high quality studio album with fresh new songs that I have written from 2013-present. Clearly, however, your investment in this project is an investment in the future of my musical career AND an investment for the community.  Your support is greatly appreciated!
Spread The Word
Kickstarter projects operate on an "all or nothing" model.  This means that if I don't meet my funding goal in 30 days, there will be no studio and no album.  So I am relying on you to spread the word.  Tell your friends, family, co-workers, neighbors, bank tellers and mail carriers.  E-mail the link.  Post it on your social media accounts.  Sing it from the rooftops.  Anything you can do to get more folks interested will go a long way in helping me out.  Thanks!
RoofTopHowl Studio
RoofTopHowl Studio is the brainchild of my friend and colleague, Craig Griffin.  Here are some examples of his work:
 The Suspense
I had a lot of fun promoting this project and thought I would include some of the pics and videos I used to do so:
PLAY

Thanks for checking out my project.  Let's do this thing!  And don't forget to tell a friend.

updates.update_userinfo: New EP from my band, Some Hollow
updates.update_content:
Hello,
I'm happy to announce that I have a studio recording to share with you! 
https://somehollow.bandcamp.com/album/green
This is a 5 song EP recorded in December with my band, Some Hollow.

I am fully aware that this album is embarrassingly tardy. I finally bit the bullet and went into a real studio to record some songs. My band, Some Hollow, went into the studio in early December and recorded 5 songs. I just went into the same studio today and recorded 9 songs. I will go in again in January to record another 2 or 3 songs and for Some Hollow to put the finishing touches on our EP.
While my Kickstarter album will be about 2 years later than planned, the advantage to you is that I will be including the Some Hollow EP when I begin shipping. Below is a rough mix of our song, Don't Call Me Baby (man I really love that pedal steel guitar!). I just added a bass track to this song today, so it'll be that much better.

https://soundcloud.com/jason-lee-187/inside-my-head-1
I spent a good chunk of the day in the studio today and felt like it was a VERY productive session.

Wrong link in the last email.  Here's the right one:
Meet Me in the Morning

I just recorded this cover of Bob Dylan tonight in my studio. Check out my new website and take a listen:

Meet Me in the Morning

It's been over a month since I gave an update, so I figured I'd check in. I have been working on recording rhythm guitar and vocal tracks and am making good progress. Good, but slow. My schedule only allows me to sneak out to the studio for a few hours at a time every 2 or 3 days. I have a week of vacation in February that coincides with my wife's February break from school, so I plan to be in the studio every day during that time. At this point I would say things are on schedule for the planned release in June, but you never know what can happen with projects like this.

The recording studio is nearly finished. I just have some trim work to do and I need to get sound treatment for the walls, but all the big stuff is done and I've already started moving equipment in. As soon as I have the sound treatment in place, the recording shall begin in earnest. 
BIG HUGE thanks to Chuck Besterman, Bob Krebs, Dolf Wirsing and Kevin Winch for volunteering their time to help make this thing happen. And REAL BIG HUGE thanks to John and Linda Lake for watching the boys so often while this was happening.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We have tried to address most of the production challenges before our campaign by building one of the four mold cavities. Since our tooling and manufacturing partner reside in the Philadelphia area, we do not have any overseas vendors. We anticipate local vendors will make for smoother production schedule and a small carbon footprint.

We knew that building the first cavity would be a bear because of the tight tolerances. Now our mold maker has perfected his technique and we anticipate the rest of the family mold cavities to be produced according to schedule. We realize mold making is an art form and it may take a little longer to tweak the mold for perfect fit.

Our team is comprised of seasoned veterans that have experience bringing products to market.

updates.update_content:
Dear TAPTOOL backers,
The production run is complete. The parts are done. I will package this weekend and ship early next week.
Have a great weekend.
best

Dear Backers,
I wish this was the update you have been waiting for, yet the saga continues..........
Over the last week we finally dialed in on the plastic mix for the TAPTOOL. However in performing the several plastic tests we found a part thickness issue that must be resolved before doing a large run.

TAPTOOL Backers,
I would like to thank everyone for ¨hanging in there¨ and being supportive for this manufacturing process. If something could possible go wrong, it has.
There is a light on the horizon. We are scheduled to have our plastic compounded this Thursday by our compounder in NJ. It should take a few days to ship to our injection molder, hopefully by mid next week. Then we will test the mix and start the production run late next week. After I have enough TAPTOOLs  , I will fulfill Kickstarter rewards immediately. I speculate fulfillment will start the week of March 16th. As soon as start fulfillment, I will post another update and celebrate.

Dear Backers,
For those of you who received your rewards I hope you have found them to be a successful accessory for your Ipads and other smart devices. I have received many complements and a few criticisms; I hope they allow you to interface with your screen more accurately, comfortably and without smudge.
As for those who are still waiting for you rewards. I can give you an update. When we first received the compounded plastic and began the initial production run, the TAPTOOLs were too hard and non compliant. In turn, we mixed the plastic with the material we had left over from our initial testing to do a small run and fulfill 1/2 of the Kickstarter backers.  We were initially told by the plastics compounder that the mix we would use to soften our original batch would be ready in 2-3 weeks. Today i got off the phone and received news of another delay. He is hoping that he will be able to supply the mix in 2-3 weeks (with fingers crossed).

The good news is that 225# orders of TAPTOOL were shipped last Friday and should be delivered by now according to my tracking info. I hope you like my product and thank you for your support.
The initial 225# orders were filled using the rest of our R and D material in order to conserve raw material product. This run of TAPTOOL met my ideal standard. We even tried to regrind the sprue material but were unsuccessful in an effort to extend the # of TAPTOOLs produced.

campaign.story:
"Madman in the Gate" is a collection of songs and poems accompanied by artwork and photographs from some of the top artists around the world.  I went to people like comic book artist Don Kramer (Batman, Wonder Woman), Halloween/Horror artist Scott Jackson, famed fashion photographers Sandford Porter, London's Darren Ball and Katherine Jones, Akiko Matsuoka Thorson, Montana nature photographer Brian Delaurenti, renowned sculptor William Marhofer, well known Midwest artists Ken Stark, Pilar Acevedo, Richard Benoit, Peter Pagast, Chris Shoup, Alicia Post Keith Neimeyer and Michael Costanza  New York photographers Samantha Nandez, Mike Pecci and Nicole Myers, Southern California artists Alan Swartz  and Samantha Lockwood, Internet phenom Liquid, Hawaii's John Garrett, Thailand’s Prisana Nuechterlein, Germany's Grzegorz Lepiarz and many, many more.  There are over a hundred four-color illustrations in the book.  
To be honest, I got so carried away with the beauty and artistic potential of the book that the print costs became very expensive.  I was only able to print a short run and that sold out very quickly.  Now I am looking for funding to do a larger scale printing.  Please consider helping me.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Though I have written 33 books, getting a new book published and/or distributed is always a challenge. The easiest way is to complete the book first so that publishers know what they're buying and once the book is completed it can be offered as an e-book or printed on demand basis which sometimes can reach more people than conventional means. There is somewhat of a demand at present for full color e-books because there is a limited amount of those available for people who have color readers.

"Madman in the Gate" has a broader appeal than most poetry books because it included such a great collection of works by artists and photographers from all over the world. Naturally, we will try to reach that audience in our marketing. The overall key to sales is being able to find your target audience. The challenge, as always in publishing, is getting the word out to people. I have done this before. My book "The Platinum Rainbow" was self published and sold 250,000 copies. Once I've done the research and written the book, I can find the audience.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Hello! Did you miss our Kickstarter campaign? You can now find Torso in our online store at: http://www.richardtracybrand.com
Love for Torso:
Tech Crunch: "torso is the charger cable transformed"
AndroidSPIN: "stupid simple and perfect for any Android enthusiast"
Geek Dad: “been using mine for a week now and really like it”
Android Police: "may actually be the most versatile"
TUAW: “oh-so-portable”
Android Authority: "a great cable to carry around"
Techaeris: "a CES 2014 stand out"
Android Community: "perfect for stuffing into bags"
Love for Torso's grandpa, Twig:
CNET: "most innovative iPhone docking cable ever"
WALL STREET JOURNAL: "belongs next to the register in every Apple store"
ENGADGET: "from dismembered action-figure prototype to reality"
MASHABLE: "on our 'why didn’t I think of that' list"
WIRED: "ideally suited to charging in laptops"
CULT OF MAC: "the design is ingenius"
9 TO 5 MAC: "the most versatile iPhone charging cord"
Introduction.

The cable that comes with your phone gets the job done, but it's not very portable. And if you're on-the-go all the time, then you know that yanking that cable out of your bag is a hassle. It gets caught on stuff in your bag. It pulls other crap out of there too--keys, pens, other cables, you name it!
Say hello to Torso.
Torso is incredibly short, so it's ultra-portable. It's a little bit over 4 inches (100+ mm) long, so it's the perfect phone cable for anyone who is on-the-go. But Torso's size isn't the only thing it has going for it. We have designed Torso with a bendable wire "skeleton" and three "legs". These bendable legs are what make Torso so amazing.
Bend it.
The wire skeleton inside Torso isn't a limp noodle like those old bendable toys. Torso is strong. Bend a leg, and it stays bent. Bend all three legs, and make a tripod. Bend Torso and plug it into your AC adapter to make an instant wall charger dock. And when you want to hit the road, just bend Torso back into ultra-portable mode and chuck it in your bag. It's like no other cable, and it's awesome.
What can you do with Torso and your phone?
- Ultra-portable mode: Sync and charge on the go.
- Wall charger mode: Charge your phone right on the outlet.
- Tripod mode: Snap fun tripod photos on the go.
- Tripod mode: Pose for perfect self-timer (or Pebble assisted) photos.
- Tripod mode: FaceTime with friends: on the go and hands-free!
- Cord Wrap mode: Save space with the best earbud cord wrap.
- Widescreen mode: Watch a movie or the game in widescreen mode.
Tripod mode: hands-free FaceTime
Wall charger mode: keep your phone off the floor
Ultra-portable mode: charge and sync on the go
Cord Wrap mode: ultra-portable convenience
Widescreen mode: watch the Timbers match
PLAY

 Tripod mode: self-timer (or Pebble assisted) remote photos
Be sure to select your reward so that it matches your phone! And note that the Micro-USB version will work with just about *any* phone that has the Micro-USB connector centered on the bottom!
Ultra-portable mode: with the iPhone 5C and Galaxy S4
Into production.
We launched Twig last year right here on Kickstarter. A lot has changed since then. New connectors. New phones! And we've got a new name for our product, too. Torso will now be Made for iPhone--with the Lightning connector for the iPhone 5, 5C, and 5S. Torso is also great for Samsung Galaxy S3, S4, other Android phones, and many more devices and accessories--with the Micro-USB connector! We've already launched two great products with the Kickstarter community, and now we need your help to launch Torso as well.
Prototyping: our original Twig video and the evolution of Torso
If you've backed one of our other projects like Twig or Wide Body, then you know that our crew is big on prototyping. We aren't afraid to rip stuff apart, scratch our heads a bit, and then glue it all back together in almost-unimaginable new ways. In fact, it's just that kind of design and prototyping that led to Torso. You can see this process in action in our Kickstarter videos for Twig and Wide Body. We've already completed most of the prototyping for Torso, and now it's time to build our production tooling for the project.
And that's where your support will help us. Funding for this project will pay for plastic injection molds, wire forming fixtures, elastomer over-mold tooling, and much more. Our supplier already makes cables for the iPhone, so (believe it or not) the electrical wiring and connectors for Torso will be the easy part.
Thank you very much.
UTENSILE is a product development company in Portland, Oregon. We design and develop consumer electronics products for companies like Apple, Intel, Dell, and Nike--and we have brought dozens of products through mass production for our clients over the years. Our team is really excited about Torso, but launching a product like this on our own is something that just doesn't pencil-out without the right kind of funding up front. In other words, this is the perfect kind of project for Kickstarter. Thank you so much. And please share this project with your friends! If they have a smart phone, chances are that they will love Torso too.
Check out "Power Happy" from Portland's own Con Bro Chill on Facebook and Youtube! Patents pending. Copyright 2013 Richard Tracy LLC. Torso is a registered trademark of Richard Tracy LLC. iPhone, iPod, and FaceTime are registered trademarks of Apple Inc. Android is a registered trademark of Google Inc. The Android robot is reproduced from work created and shared by Google and used according to terms described in the Creative Commons 3.0 Attribution License.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This isn't our first rodeo, but product development is a bumpy road. Kickstarter is a fun and transparent way for backers to "go along for the ride" while we make new things. And we love that. We didn't have many problems at all during our Twig project! Our Wide Body project ran into some issues with our leather, but we ironed those out in front of our backers with plenty of updates to let them know what was happening. And we delivered only a few weeks late (not months or years!) on both projects.

Made for iPhone (MFi) certification is another challenge as we move into production on Torso. We have already passed many of the tests required for MFi, but there are still a few more to go, and Apple has very strict quality, design, and packaging guidelines for its accessory development partners. MFi certification is important because it ensures that our products will function just as well as Apple's stock cables. We are looking forward to displaying the Made for iPhone branding on Torso's packaging with pride.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Kickstarters,
Guess what? Almost a year in the making--it’s finally done! It’s time to ship Torso Lightning rewards. Seriously? Seriously.
Here's what you need to do:
1) If your address is still the same, then you don’t need to do anything. If you have submitted your backer survey—that’s perfect. If you have moved and have already updated your address with us, then you are good to go.

Kickstarters,
I just returned from 18 days in China—the second longest trip in my entire career. I’d like to say that I got to spend that time focusing on Torso, but that’s not the case. Our core business is still providing product development and engineering services for other clients, and that’s what my team was doing over there. However, on the last day of my trip, I visited the Torso factory for an hour. And it was a great hour! I got to see the production line (video snapshot attached) and—best of all—the factory finally provided a schedule.

Kickstarters,
First the good news. Apple’s MFi certification process for Torso Lightning is now complete. This is outstanding news that’s only attenuated by the long journey that our team went through to get us here. I’m so happy about this. It has been quite a ride.
Now for the news news. The schedule for mass production is still TBD. The tools are ready to go! But because of the global push to build hundreds of millions (!) of accessories for the new phone launch, there’s currently a shortage of Lightning connectors in our supplier’s factory. With Torso’s new MFi certification, we’re now in the queue for the next available connectors. The factory tells me that this could happen in the middle of October. Not ideal, but there it is. So now I’m planning to ship rewards to you in November.

Kickstarters,
We received our final production samples for Torso Lightning on Friday, and they are perfect. There are some red tape, production, and logistics issues in the mix--but it looks like we’re still “on track” for October. I cannot wait to ship Torso Lightning. I know you can’t wait either, so thanks for hanging in there.
Also of note: I am going to be in China from August 26th (yep—tomorrow) through September 12th. Internet traffic via email and many websites is handled… differently… over there. If I’m not able to post an update while I’m over there, please stand-by and I’ll get one out when I return. And if you need to get in touch with one of us for any reason, you can always email info@richardtracybrand.com.

Kickstarters,
It is 92 degrees F (33 C) in Portland. I’m in the office, and the AC is out, so I’ll keep this update brief. While many backers are happy that they’re already enjoying their Torso Micro-USB and Torso 30-pin rewards, I can understand that you Torso Lightning backers can’t wait to join in the fun, too. Hang in there! We’re working on it.
It feels good to know that the other two products are out there in the world, but the project won’t feel whole to me until we ship Torso Lightning. I’m now estimating delivery in October for Torso Lightning. New samples off the new tooling are due this week, and I will share photos (and less dog photos) when they come in. Stay cool out there, enjoy the summer, and thank you for supporting this project!

Kickstarters,
We received 400 Torso Micro-USBs last night. The rest of the order with the bulk of the Torso Micro-USBs and Torso 30-pins will arrive today or tomorrow. We’ll start sending these out to you... today. They’re here!
Best regards,
Jason

Kickstarters,
Torso Micro-USB and Torso 30-pin backers: we’re so close.
The latest funny(?) anecdote: believe it or not, our freight forwarder left our pallets in Los Angeles for a while after clearing customs, and then they stuck your Torsos on a *train* to Seattle (for reference: wrong city, 173 miles *past* Portland). The train arrives in Seattle on Monday. Then they’ll load the pallets on a truck for the drive from Seattle to Portland. Once they arrive, we’ll load each Torso into an envelope and send them to you.

Kickstarters,
Torso Micro-USB and Torso 30-pin are almost here, so we’re getting ready to send your reward packages. I’m pretty excited about this, as fulfillment is one of the most satisfying parts of these projects. Sealing each envelope is literally a small amount of closure to a long adventure of a project.
Address changes: this probably does not affect you, as most backers have already turned-in their surveys: but if you haven’t submitted your backer survey yet, please do so now. And if you need to change your address, then please do so within the next 72 hours. Changing your address is easy:

Kickstarters,
Torso Micro-USB and Torso 30-pin are on a container ship on the way to the US. They should be in our office at the end of May or beginning of June, and then we’ll deliver them to you folks asap.
So I'm pretty happy about Torso Micro-USB and Torso 30-pin, but that joy is mixed with different emotions from the other part of the project, Torso Lightning.

Kickstarters,
I’ve got some not-great news for this update. We had a delay in procuring our packaging materials for Torso Micro-USB and Torso 30-pin, so we will not get those units into the US until mid-May. This means that our rewards will not go out to you until June.
The good news? The packaging looks really good! Packaging may seem like something “extra” or superfluous, but it’s very important for making Torso available for sale at retail stores. And that’s the dream!

My micro-USB got here today! Packaging is great, the device looks and feels pretty solid. It does indeed stay bent pretty much the way you mean for it to. Everything seems to work fine, it even holds up my huge Galaxy Note 3. The only problem I have is that the micro-usb plug is backwards. I tried to plug in my phone just like the little picture on the box and it ends up showing me the back of my phone. That's not really as useful. I ended up having to twist the main center piece of the torso a full 180 and then it works like it should, but I was nervous bending it that much. It didn't really feel like it was meant to be twisted that hard. Perhaps I'm just not familiar, but encouraging all the Galaxy phones to use this and then having the main USB plug backwards from what the imagery implies seems like a major mistake to me. Maybe there are phones out there with the connector on the phone reversed so it will work naturally, but I was a little disappointed to see it turn out this way. By no means does it hurt the MAIN purpose of the device, it's just a niggling issue I have with it. It still feels very weird to put all the weight of my phone on top of a micro-usb connector that bends, but so far it seems to work okay. I'll admit I don't think it will last a long time, but it's mostly a novelty device to me and should come in handy every once in a while. Only time will tell how many people end up snapping the connector off in the bottom of their phones.
PS: More colors in the future? Maybe? Just wondering. :)
