campaign.story:
Wow! You've inspired us to THINK and DREAM Bigger! Now let's DO it!
Thank you Kickstarter fans, friends, and sriracha-lovers for the amazing support over the past 40 days! Not only have you been able to help us raise the capital we need to start a great season for our sriracha production, but you've also inspired and encouraged us to keep doing what we are doing.
We are now ready to take the next step to grow our business and continue making delicious and healthy sauces and making it available to more people. 
Thank you! 
- Lisa
 Vice.com"Sriracha aged in whiskey barrels is better than the original sauce." 
San Francisco Magazine says our sriracha "hurts so good." 
Chow.com "A woman in SF is barrel-aging sriracha and it's awesome!"
Cool Hunting says "The aging process seems to pull a slight smokiness from the barrels as well, while the fermentation allows the red chili peppers to develop an authentic fruity flavor, giving it a more layered personality than most hot sauces."
Carolyn Jung, an award winning food writer and author of San Francisco Chef’s Table profiled our sauces:  “It’s far fruitier than the Red Rooster Sriracha, and less sweet, too. From the first taste, you know you’re enjoying a real artisan product made with a lot of thought.”
Marcia Gagliardi of TableHopper, 7x7 Magazine admitted "It's like unlike any product I’ve ever tasted: it’s balanced, a touch smoky (and garlicky), and simply amazing" Read Marcia's full review here. 
You've told us "You had me at Barrel-Aged" "Love your passion and drive with your new kickstarter project. Keep it up!" 
Hi Kickstarter!
I'm Lisa, the Chief Sauce Maker at Sosu Sauces. It's my passion to make tastier, healthier, and wildly creative versions of everyday sauces. Last year on Kickstarter, we invited you to rediscover ketchup with our first sauce, Srirachup, a perfect marriage of our house-blend sriracha and ketchup. 7x7 Magazine named as one of the Best Local Gems of San Francisco and we were honored as a Good Food Award Finalist for this delicious sauce.
Now we are on a mission to make improvements upon another sauce—sriracha.
We age our sriracha in whiskey barrels!
We combined our philosophy of using fresh, locally sourced ingredients with the age-old craft of fermentation. We age our secret pepper mash in whiskey barrels for between 1-3 months. The sriracha takes on complex flavors from the oak barrels and the natural fermentation process. Absolutely no preservatives or additives go into our sriracha. Each bottle is handcrafted and made in small batches to ensure the most intense flavors.
Our ingredients are simple: chili peppers, brown sugar, garlic, and salt. No potassium sorbate or Sodium Bisulfite.
When we tasted the first batch of our Barrel-Aged Sriracha, we knew we were onto something big. The flavors are spicy, fruity, and had a lingering smokiness from the oak barrels. It is Sriracha, but one that we’ve never tasted quite like this before.
Limited Edition Barrel-Aged Sriracha, aged for 3 months
As with whiskey, the aging time greatly impacts the flavor of our sriracha. We normally age our sriracha for one month in order to preserve the bright, fruity flavor of the peppers. But we are releasing a limited-edition Barrel-Aged Sriracha aged for 3 month exclusively for our Kickstarter supporters. This additional time in the whiskey barrels brings out a sweeter, more robust, and smokier flavors of the oak barrels to create a balance in the spiciness. 
Barrel-Aged Hot Sauce and Sriracha Salt
But wait, there's more. Our waste-not, want not philosophy inspired us to create two additional products from the by-products of our sriracha—Barrel-Aged Hot Sauce and Sriracha Salt.
Oysters not included, but a good pairing with the hot sauce!
Barrel Aged Hot Sauce is our version of a vinegar-based hot sauce. Also aged in whiskey barrels, we soak the leftover pepper skin and seeds from our sriracha to create a spicy, tangy, and fruity and perfectly balanced hot sauce. Full of flavor, it's good stuff. (4oz)
Our Sriracha Salt will become your favorite go-to seasoning. It’s spicy, nutty, lightly roasted with a hint of oak and goes well on anything (especially pizza!).
Barrel-Aged Swags - Showing your love for #BarrelAgedSriracha
Stretch Goals and Rewards: 
Our long-term goal has always been to have a dedicated production facility, build a strong team, and launch new products. With your continued support, we can achieve these goals even sooner! We are announcing stretch goals of $60,000 and $100,000 to help us get to those goals. Take a look at what we can accomplish if we are to meet these stretch goals:
The Stretch Goal Rewards: 
 $60,000 stretch goal reward: Everyone who orders a jar of Barrel-Aged Sriracha will receive a FREE Sriracha Cumin Spice Rub. The inspiration comes from my recent trip to Xi'an, China, where cuimin spicy lamb skewers are a popular Muslim-Chinese street food snack. The rub is made with lightly toasted ground cumin mixed with dried Barrel-Aged Sriracha pepper flakes, perfect for every meat dish (especially lamb)!
$100,000 stretch goal reward: Everyone who orders a jar of Barrel-Aged Sriracha will receive a FREE 4 oz Whiskey Barrel-Aged Sambal Oelek. Sambal oelek is a staple Southeast Asian chili sauce meaning “ground chili sambal", essentially a thick sriracha with the pepper seeds and skin. Our version combines plenty of garlic, fish sauce, and lime juice with Whiskey-Barrel Aged pepper mash for a rich and umami flavor. The perfect sidekick for dumplings!
Our Journey
Our barrel-aging journey starts with local farmers who help us grow the peppers (April, 2013)
Our whiskey barrels getting ready for their the sriracha mash. (September, 2013)
In late summer, we are ready for our production (October, 2013)
Loading up our first barrel (October, 2013)
With your support
Your Kickstarter contribution will be instrumental in making our Barrel-Aged Sriracha a reality. It will provide us with the initial capital to work with local farmers and buy the starter seeds and to invest in important facilities and equipment for the upcoming 2014 season as we go to market with our Barrel-Aged Sriracha. 
With your help, we made a better ketchup, now let’s re-invent sriracha together!
Sincerely,
Special Thanks to:
John Liau - Our amazing videographer
Seth Tsui - Talented music composer who put together the awesome music for our video 
Carolyn Edgecomb - Our amazing designer, who creates and makes things beautiful. Email her at carolyn(dot)edgecomb(at)gmail.com if you need design help!
Kyle Zaylor - Wonderful roommate/Chief Guinea Pig (CGP) and video editor
Our Sosu fans and you!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
When we chose to work with fresh ingredients, we know how variable the weather and conditions can impact the variability and volume of our products. That's why we have decided to work with multiple farmers this year to ease that risk. 

Barrel-Aged Sriracha is a new product for us, however not a new operation for Sosu. We have successfully fulfilled our 1st Kickstarter project and were able to launch our ketchups to San Francisco bay area and are now carried by more than 20 retailers and online. We also have a track record of scaling up a business, from processing 4,000 lbs of fresh ingredients in the first year to 10,000 lbs in the second year.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hi Sosu fans!
Time flies too quickly. Can you believe it’s been a year since you helped us get our Barrel-Aged Sriracha off the ground? We hope you have been enjoying your sriracha and had a good time sharing them with your loved ones. You might be wondering how we are doing or what we have been up to. We have some very exciting news to share with you! 
We are in Sur La Table nationwide and more Bay Area stores!

updates.update_userinfo: Hard work pays off. More stores. And recipe inspirations!
updates.update_content:
Hi Saucy Fans, 
Barrel-Aged Sriracha is heading your way! 
After 3 days of NON-STOP fulfillment and a team of the best, and hardest working folks, 1500 + packages of Barrel-Aged Sriracha goodness is coming your way! I am so proud of our team during this entire fulfillment process. We ran into challenges along the way, but conquered them with teamwork.

updates.update_userinfo: The last of shipments, ordering more, & special offer for our KS backers!
updates.update_content:
Hi Sosu Fans, 
We are getting very close to shipping your Barrel-Aged Sriracha! In order to help us make fulfillment as easy as possible, if you have moved, it is extremely IMPORTANT that you update your address no later than tomorrow, Sunday (December 7th) at 6pm PST. This is the FINAL reminder for all address changes. Otherwise, we will have sent your sauces to the wrong person!

updates.update_userinfo: Barrel-Aged Sriracha is Coming Your Way!
updates.update_content:
Hi Saucy fans, 
First of all, thank you for your patience and understanding in our new delivery date. As bummed as we are in getting Barrel-Aged goodness to your hands at a later date, it's very important that our sriracha is fully aged in whiskey barrels for an month and 3 months to achieve our unique flavor. 
One of the challenges this year with scaling up our production was sourcing of peppers. We had started contract growing with our farmers back in March, but due to the California drought and an unusually short season, we received less peppers than expected and later than expected. Because of the delay in getting our peppers, we ended up a month behind our planned schedule.

updates.update_userinfo: Final Reminder for Address Changes & Local Pick-ups

campaign.story:
Click the picture for our feature in Yahoo!
Update #7 The Hula Hoopin' Gardener
What is the Ring Weeder and how does it work ?
The Ring Weeder is a garden tool that slips onto your index finger that helps when pulling weeds by hand in those densely planted areas where larger tools wont fit. Hand weeding is still the most convenient method of weed control and this tool is designed to help you better extract the root of the weed. Weeds are tricky, and if you don't get the whole root, the weed will grow back. The Ring Weeder allows you to get the whole root which will save you time and effort in the long run. Better weeding, fewer weeds.
Vegetable gardens, flower beds, and every space in between, they all need to be weeded. We want to improve this process so you spend less time weeding and more time enjoying the fruits of your labor.
Even if you don't weed yourself you know someone that does. So get them one, it makes a great gift.
Here's how it works:
Research and Development
While weeding a flower bed using this screw driver-like tool (pictured below), I came up with the idea of a tool that attaches to my hand to make the weeding quicker and more efficient. I was frustrated while using the screwdriver-like tool since I am right handed and didn't like to use my left hand to pull out the weed which forced me to put the tool down and then pull out the weed with my preferred hand. This made for a slow and boring process.
The highlight of my frustration was when one day I misplaced the tool and spent twenty minutes searching for it since I didn't want to run it over with my lawn mower and risk damaging the machine or even worse: potentially hitting someone with it.  
Screw driver-like weeding tool
Images of a tool that attached directly to my hand started to bounce around in my head. 
My original idea and first drawing
On the day after Thanksgiving, 2012, I searched for a welder to make my prototype. After being rejected by one welder, and another not returning my call, I decided to stop by Tom Malloy’s Welding Shop in Glen Head, NY. After carefully explaining my idea, Tom went to work quickly on what was dubbed "The Garden Claw".
"The Claw" was very awkward to use so I went back to the drawing board to refine the concept.
I realized that using only the tool on my index finger along with the help of my bare thumb felt more natural and comfortable. My next thought was 'What if I had a long metal finger nail to get under the weed instead?'. This next prototype was dubbed "The Garden Nail". After testing, it was clear that rotating the nail tip under the finger greatly improved leverage and comfort. Soon after, the name "The Ring Weeder" emerged since you actually slip the device on you finger like a ring.
My first workable design. Now I'm on the right track!
  After getting my patent pending, I reached out to local State Colleges and Universities and this is how I met Mechanical Engineer and future Project Advisor, Dr. Jeff Hung.
With his advice, I conducted my own research to find the average size of peoples fingers. The finger width along with the glove is vital in fitting of The Ring Weeder. My research suggested that offering two sizes: A large and a small version would fit most fingers. Dr. Hung then suggested a small slit on the top of the tool to allow for some flexibility to make an improved fit. You can find the best size for your Ring Weeder in the FAQ.
I used the caliper tool to measure peoples ring size up to the first knuckle
The only question left was what material to make the tool out of. ABS plastic was the number one choice for its strength, durability, and lightweight properties. This resilient material is commonly used in the making of protective headgear, small kitchen appliances, and toys like Legos.
 I choose orange as my first production run color because it is bright and easy to locate amongst clutter or if misplaced in the field. 
Prototype Computer Image
The Final Prototype!
 With the help of your pledges I will be able to get the tooling needed ( cavity mold) and the first production run of your Ring Weeder. The research and development was done in NY. The final production will be done overseas. We already have a quote from an injection molding company for the molds and the production. The cavity mold will take about 8 weeks to make upon my ordering it. So once i am funded I can place the order. 
So that’s my story and this is my project. Thank you so much for looking at my project and learning more about it. I hope you will take part in my vision to help me launch this new and innovative tool.  
 SO REMEMBER, EVEN IF YOU DONT WEED YOURSELF, YOU KNOW SOMEONE THAT DOES. IT MAKES A GREAT GIFT!
AND REMEMBER, LET THE RING, BE YOUR WEEDER!!!
Kickstarter Launch gloves also available in dark grey
How to size your Ring Weeder
http://g-ecx.images-amazon.com/media/i3d/01/ring-size-finder.pdf
Goals
What are my short term goals?
1. Tooling for my cavity mold
2. First production run of your Ring Weeder
Stretch Goals
1. Develop a carrying case  
2.  Have The Ring Weeder available in different colors
Future plans
3. Secure my patent 
4. Show it at trade shows
5. Sell it at major retail stores
Acknowledgements
A special thank you goes out to my wife Anna for her constant support these past seven months. Also to my mom for shooting that last scene in my video. It was so much fun and a memory I will cherish forever.

One risk would be a delay in shipment date due to quality issues for the first production run. However we are using a trusted manufacturer so we do not expect any issues, but we will be prepared for the unexpected.

Communicating how to choose the best fit the tool with your glove will be a challenge we hope to best address in the FAQ's and in the comments section. We want every backer to have the best experience possible when they first receive their tool.

Risks and challenges
The biggest risk of this project for me as a creator is making the best comics I can with the stories that are submitted. But that's also the challenge I can't wait to tackle. 

I have a printer here in Chicago ready to go and a plan to take care of shipping. In order to prepare for any blunders that could come with taking submissions, I have created a few stipulations for this end of the project:

• By submitting a story to me, you're giving me full non-exclusive rights to the story, including the rights to illustrate it, change it, sell it, etc. 
• I do not have to use your story if it does not make the book more awesome. (Signing up for the $1 tier gives you the right to submit a story to be considered by me, but it does not guarantee that I will use it in the book. You will get a copy for $1, regardless.)
• I will connect with backers via Kickstarter once the project closes, and I will ask for your submissions and photos.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Thank you. More updates coming, including a survey to retrieve your stories. For now, I'm gonna bum around New York. I just passed the Ocean Cafe, which we can all agree is pretty rad considering it was here where Meg Ryan starts to build her in-person relationship with the perfect Tom Hanks in the classic film "You've Got Mail." Why are you still reading this update?

Let's Be Awkward Together is funded. Because of the incredible generosity of you, YOU, this book is happening.
The picture below is what I looked like when I woke up to a funded project, on the verge of crying and disbelief. 
Then someone cancelled their pledge, and the same picture below is what I looked like when I found out. The lesson here is that we are not done! Let's get a little over the goal and the project will be funded, even if pledges are cancelled last minute or accounts are over drawn. Such is the life, the drama of running of a Kickstarter.

Let's Be Awkward Together is 76% funded! Again, why can't we capitalize numbers? Feels like we're missing out on something there....
With only 13 days left and a quarter of the way to go, these last two weeks of the project are the most important. I feel like writing to y'all at this point is just preaching to the choir, but there is only one way we can get this project funded. Tell your friends/family/coworkers/post it on your blog and I will be forever grateful.

campaign.story:
Exit Ramp: A Short Case Study of the Profitability of Panhandling
Have you ever wondered how much money that guy with the cardboard sign makes? I did...and I decided to find out. Over the summer of 2012, while pursuing a degree in economics, I took my education out of the classroom to answer one simple question—how much does a panhandler make?
The answers available seemed to be more urban legend than plausible fact. Some say a panhandler earns a below substance-level income. Some say he can earn forty-thousand, sixty-thousand, or even eighty-thousand a year. With nothing really substantial to go on, I decided to, quantitatively, find out the answer for myself.
The answer was waiting down at the exit ramp. I grew out my beard, donned some worn clothes, and built my very own cardboard sign. I panhandled for eighty hours over the course of twelve days. While incognito, I secretly recorded as much economic information as possible—the gender of the donor, the time of day I received donations, the approximate age of donors, and more.
Of course, most important of all, I recorded how much money I earned. Get out your two-week pay stub. By the end of my book, you will find out if you make more or less than that guy you see every day at the exit ramp.
This will not be a dry economic textbook. There are human stories to tell. I am writing this book to tell about the woman who gave me a single hundred dollar bill and the teenage boy who gave me four pennies. About the Army vet who threatened to punch me in the face and ended up giving me twenty dollars. About the woman who offered me a job the first day I started panhandling. Do you believe America is a generous society or are we just a collection of banksters? I think I found part of the answer, and it’s worth sharing.
What I am asking from the Kickstarter community is help to get this economic tale of investigative journalism from raw data into written word and out to the public. I have already made substantial progress. Approximately one third of the book is written. I need a small degree of financial backing so that I can complete the manuscript and cover the modest costs of book design, editing, and publication. I can do all this on a shoestring budget—I just need someone to help provide the shoestrings. 
 What I am offering in return is a way for interested readers to pre-purchase the finished product. The story of my adventures panhandling is a story worth being told—but don’t take my word for it. Below is the introduction of the manuscript. If you enjoy it and want to read more, please feel free to support my work as your means allow. Thank you for your consideration and any spare change. 
PS. If you find this as fascinating a topic as I did, please share my work with others so they too can explore the profitability of panhandling. Cheers. 
                Manuscript for Exit Ramp
                        -Introduction-
“The practical uses of economic studies should never be out of the mind of the economist, but his special business is to study and interpret facts and to find out what are the effects of different causes acting singly and in combination.” -Alfred Marshall
            All across the highways and byways of America a common phenomenon occurs. Take any exit into a metropolitan destination and the odds are good you will see a man standing at the street corner with a cardboard sign. The sign will tug at your heartstrings or appeal to your sense of humor; it will ultimately be a plea for charity. The goal of the man and his sign is the exchange of money.  
            The men—and women—who occupy the street corner go by many different names: beggars, transients, panhandlers, and bums. They don’t fit into the greater American mythology; they are an unsightly blight on our land of opportunity where success is viewed as a ripe fruit just waiting to be plucked by those willing to make the effort. The bum standing at the exit ramp is often an uncomfortable reminder of failure and poverty.  
            I suspect that I am like the majority of drivers. I try to read the various signs while earnestly endeavoring to avoid that awkward moment of eye contact. I hate that first look where the transient gazes expectantly with sorrowful eyes. My first thought is always, “Get a job!” At the risk of sounding like an uncharitable scrooge, I can’t remember ever having rolled down my window in charity. No, I always seem be the one irritably stuck behind the person with the kinder heart—while the light is green and traffic jams up. 
          Even though panhandlers have thus far been unable to open my wallet, they have always piqued my curiosity. Think about it: have you ever wondered how much a panhandler makes? It’s an interesting question. Basic economics teaches that there must be some incentive for a person to stand on a corner hat in hand. The panhandler must receive some amount of money that makes the effort worthwhile. If he did not receive any handouts, no matter how much he was down on his luck, he would be forced to seek other means of gaining money. Intuitively, we all understand this—no one would panhandle if it did not work. And since panhandling does work, the question that has always nagged me is: how well does it work?
             As this question really took hold of my economic curiosity, I started asking it in a slightly different manner: what can a transient make per hour? If I could compare panhandling at an exit ramp with earning a wage during the typical forty hour work week, which would be the more profitable?
            It’s easy to jump to the conclusion that someone without a job is, by default, worse off than someone gainfully employed, but how do we know for sure?  If we were to judge just by sight, then the appearance of the scrungy street souls with their beat up cardboard signs and dirty faces leads us to quick conclusions. Indeed, the question, visually,seems to answer itself. 
           Yet, looks can be deceiving.  If panhandling, despite all appearances, can earn a man minimum wage, then is it not possible the transient at the exit ramp has the same financial opportunities as anyone else? A beggar could have the same financial means as the kid straight out of high school starting his first job.
            To satisfy my growing curiosity of how much a transient can make per hour (and consequently, to find out if he makes more or less than a wage earner), I found myself needing hard data and a way to compare incomes. The idea for this book took shape as I took steps to collect that data. This case study, which grew out of the simple curiosity of how much a panhandler makes in a day, is my attempt to answer, quantitatively, the question of profitability in relation to panhandling.  
              With this empirical goal in mind, I decided the best course of action would be to build a little economic engine of my own.  Over the summer break of my senior year at college, while double majoring in political science and economics, I put my education to good use and started collecting data on panhandling. This is my first attempt as an aspiring economist at basic quantitative analysis and social study.    
            What follows are the adventures I experienced while building a usable data set. The numbers and stories, the spreadsheets and anecdotes—they are all the results of my going undercover as a homeless beggar and collecting the information first hand. This book chronicles my attempt to live up to the inspiring words of Alfred Marshall and never forget the “practical uses of economic studies”. I invite all those possessed of a healthy dose of curiosity and all those unafraid of spreadsheets to join me...as I go undercover at the exit ramp.
      Want more? You can read the First chapter here. 
     Like the Facebook page to get the most current updates. 
     Or donate and read the completed work coming soon!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
"An economist is an expert who will know tomorrow why the things he predicted yesterday didn't happen today." --Laurence J. Peter.

There are risks with every project, and this one is no exception. The good news is that my risks are not catastrophic. They can at best only delay the publication of my study. 

The greatest risk of delay comes from the fact that my two-year-old son was born with biliary atresia (bad plumbing between the liver and intestine for those not up on their medical lingo). He is prone to get liver infections which can mean spending a week or so in the hospital. Knock on wood--he has not had any lately, and I don't expect this to delay the project. On the other hand, if he does have complications, writing and publishing this study will take second fiddle. This complication has a low probability of delaying the release date, but I thought you should be aware of it. 

Second, I have a family of six to provide for. I am coming to the end of my education and the corresponding support of the GI Bill. I may be required to take on a second job if my finances don't hold. With a successful Kickstarter this will not be an issue, and July is a realistic release date. Basically, any unforeseen financial troubles could force me to put family before writing. Again, I see this as having a very low chance of happening, but it is always a risk. 

This study will be published. It is not a matter of if, but when. I have done most of the hard work already, and I just need the financial capital to get it across the finish line. Thanks again for your consideration and interest.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Well this is it. Today is launch day for Exit Ramp. I would have never made it this far without your support. I wanted to send one last update to say a heartfelt thank you. 
If you are interested in some of the statistics and details behind my successful campaign, I have written a blog post exploring the numbers here. 
The Amazon listing for Exit Ramp is live if you feel so inclined to write a review of the book.

Well, the manuscript is finished, edited, and sent off to the book designer. The book even has a release date--it will be available to the public August 15.

You all will be getting your copies a little sooner than that. Soon I will be sending out a survey to get contact information so that I can send out your digital and/or paperback copies. Stay tuned!

As always, you can keep up to date on the Exit Ramp Facebook page.

I am sure a few of you might be worried by now that I have taken your donation and bet it on black in Vegas, but have no fear--it's been a while since my last update, but that's because I've been busy writing! 
The good news is that I have finished the main body of the manuscript for the book and it is  currently in the editing phase. The next steps will be: giving a few beta copies to test readers, doing another round of proofreading, and then designing the interior in book layout. Murphy's Law can always affect book launches, but as of right now (fingers crossed) I am on track to have the book finished before the end of July. This has only been possible because of your support. Thank you.

With less than ten days to go, I am closing in on two major life accomplishments--the completion of my first ever Kickstarter project, and, only slightly less important, graduating from college. May 4th will be the day I get my double diploma and the day I find out if I will be a full time writer post-graduation. 
A big hearty thanks to everyone who has supported me thus far--we are halfway to the goal!

Exit Ramp has crossed the 10% funding line thanks to many early supporters like yourself. Along with this early success, I have added a $25 reward so international supporters can get a paperback copy of the completed work. This allows me to cover the extra shipping necessary to send it overseas. If there are other ways I can make this project more accessible, don't hesitate to ask. 
As a thank you for being my first supporters, I thought I would share with you a short excerpt from Chapter One.  Here is the story of my very first donation I received at the exit ramp.

campaign.story:
Thank you for a successful campaign! To purchase items from our store, please visit www.rxmade.org.
With this gift, you can give when you get, and get when you give. ~ Spin Magazine
It’s the ultimate feel-good purchase: you’re bringing something handmade into your home, helping minimize landfill dumping, and giving money to people who need a hand up. ~ Domestica // Chicago Home & Garden
What makes them different is that they blend a strong, contemporary design sensibility with a commitment to local manufacture and sustainable materials... This is a project you’ll want to back, and not just because you’ll receive cool goodies as a reward. You can back it knowing you are doing something good for not only for sparing the landfills of Chicago, but also for two great Made in USA companies. ~ Modestics
I like to feature up and coming companies that are making quality beautiful products... RX Made manages to pull that off with ease... ~ Grassroots Modern
Driven by a strong sense of domestic loyalty, Strand Design produces entirely in Chicago with materials sourced—and often recycled—from the greater urban area, extending that ethos to all RX products as well. ~ Cool Hunting
... if he’s a man of his country, help him sponsor RX Made's Kickstarter campaign... ~ Daily Candy
Looking for a unique gift this holiday season? A Chicago company that makes furniture out of garbage may have the answer... ~ CBS
OUR STORY


Founded in 2011 by Chicago Non-Profit Rebuilding Exchange, RX Made evolved out of what was originally a job training program to create skilled workers in the growing field of building deconstruction and materials reuse.
The trainees in the program were taught basic carpentry skills, and learned to create furniture from reclaimed building materials salvaged in Chicago. From these beginnings, we have since transformed into a small furniture production shop, hiring both graduates from the training program and talented builders from the furniture making community here in Chicago.

OUR INSPIRATION

Over the past year, we’ve received such an enthusiastic response to our furniture line that we wanted to explore producing a greater variety of products utilizing reclaimed and locally produced materials. We also wanted to make these products in the same way that we make our furniture; using local sourcing, local design, and local craftspeople. We are made in the USA.

OUR PROCESS
As we started to ponder this idea, we realized we had lots of questions. What should we make? Where would we get parts that we can’t make ourselves? What could these products look like? As we looked out into the design community to help us extend our product possibilities, we reached out to Strand Design, a Chicago based firm that for four years has been designing locally manufactured products. Strand Design was a natural choice to help us launch a product line that could blend creative design with reclaimed materials, as well as help us pilot a model that supports local manufacturers and designers.
Strand has designed and fully prototyped three products specifically for RX Made, taking into account our material resources and the production capabilities of our small shop. 
Every sourcing and production detail has been considered, and with the help of Strand Design, we were able to domestically source all of the components for this project, (everything from hardware and material finishes to clock movements and laser cut steel) with most pieces coming from Chicago and the Great Lakes Region.

All we need to get started is the support of you, our backers! We are so excited with the results of this collaboration, and are so excited for everyone to be a part of helping us make this project happen!
When you support RX Made on Kickstarter, you help us:
Reclaim community "waste" and turn it into an asset
Create jobs for local designers and manufacturers, and:
Start production of the first edition of designs manufactured by
RX Made in collaboration with Strand Design
STRAND DESIGN FOR RX MADE: THE PRODUCTS
The RX Made Bottle Opener is made from reclaimed floor boards salvaged from deconstructed buildings in Chicago and locally fabricated stainless steel. The heat brand on the handle was made by a local manufacturer in Chicago, and all of the hardware is U.S. made.
The RX Made Wall Clock was designed with small scraps that accumulate in the wood shop in mind. Each clock is made from locally sourced Ash from Horigan Urban Forest Products, a unique lumber resource. Rather than contributing to deforestation, urban lumber comes from trees that would commonly be turned into mulch, burned, or otherwise destroyed; In the case of the Ash used in this design, it comes from trees that have succumbed to the Emerald Ash Borer blight. The clock is held together with a steel plate manufactured in Chicago, and U.S. made hardware. The quartz movement is manufactured in California, and the hands are manufactured in Rhode Island.
The RX Made Modular System is designed to work with reclaimed dimensional lumber, and can be made into a bench or a bookcase. If you happen to have some nice old-growth 2" x 12" boards from a recent project lying around, the DIY Kit is for you!

If you want a great bookcase or bench, we're offering both urban sourced Ash and reclaimed lumber for the shelves and bench top. The bookcase shelves are 4' wide and 11" deep, and the bench top is 5' and 11" deep. The laser cut steel components are manufactured and powder coated in Chicago. The shelves are finished with Tung oil manufactured in Iowa. All U.S. made hardware.
Detail of Reclaimed Lumber Shelves
Detail of Ash Shelves

REWARD RECAP:

SPECIAL THANKS TO:
Nick Martin Film
Snip Snap Go
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
RISKS & CHALLENGES:

In using reclaimed materials, we confront a lot more material variation and variability in our sourcing than most manufacturers, making consistent processing a constantly fun challenge. 

This is also our first production run partnering with outside manufacturers, so we will be dealing with outside factors for the first time such as potential manufacturer delays, shipping problems, etc. 

While RX Made has production experience, this is our largest production project to date.

We also will be making our first foray into shipping with this project, and while neither rain nor snow may be the case, we are preparing for the new challenges of lost items, missed addresses, and damaged goods.

Essentially, its a bigger version of what we already do, and although scaling up presents its own challenges, we feel pretty ready. We are so excited about this project!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content: Hey Folks! We have been hard at work on the benches and modular systems. The steel bases and rises have been fabricated are in the process of being powder coated (all right here in Chicago!) Meanwhile we will be hand-rubbing a tung oil finish on the reclaimed wood and ash here in the RX Made shop. We hope to be shipping them in the next week or two. Thanks so much for your patience.

This week we've been prepping all the clock parts for the assembly stage: setting up jigs, cutting the shapes out to size, drilling holes, beveling edges, sanding to perfection, and making sure all the details are just right so that all the pieces can come together next week. Check it out!

campaign.story:
Hey all! Name's Neal, and I'm heading this musical fusion that is NINO, which aims to blend and fuse North American and South American music, as well as tell the story of a journey. 
There are elements of Cumbia (originated in Colombia), Hauyno (Peruvian/Bolivian), Carnival Themes (Peru), but also electronic, pop, rock, alternative-styles, etc.
But more than anything, it's a story about a very deep experience.
Like I said in the video, I recently came back from a journey through South America that lasted for six months. I went alone, switching locations often every 3 or 4 days, going on insane adventures (and misadventures), doing amazing things and things I should NEVER have done. There was volcano climbing, stargazing in the jungle, rigging a road with rocks so the bus wouldn't tip over into a river, arriving at random towns at 3 in the morning with no place to go.
But behind all of this are experiences, relationships, lost loves...a really beautiful story of true change and, really, where that leads all of us. It's the REAL answer to the question, "How WAS it?" 
THIS is how it was.
So there are going to be lots of cultural mixings within the songs. I'll be using synthesizers, electric guitars, and electronic elements AS WELL AS the quena, the siku, the charango, the cuatro, the guiro, the djembe, and the tabla.
In fact, here's a video of some of those very instruments!
I can't WAIT for people to hear this. I want to show people something NEW, and something inspired by this crazy intangibility of a journey...this discovery of another life through one man's lens. 
The money here is going towards:
-Production (equipment, mixing/mastering, CD duplication) 
-Marketing (posters, shirts, hats, etc)
-Publicity (press kits, promoter, etc)
Thanks for all of your support! This album is going to be something really spectacular!!!
Facebook page (like it!!!!)
https://www.facebook.com/ninotheband
campaign.risks:

Other than that, the risks aren't bad! I've nearly completed the album (a few songs left to go), so that's a SURE thing, and promotion is a matter of creating the right elements, getting them to the right people, and being able to make the best connections. The artwork that all of the deliverables will have (clothing, posters, album cover, press kits, etc) is being worked on right now, so everything is really falling into place.

updates.update_userinfo: What songs do you want to see performed?
updates.update_content:
Hello beautiful fan-people! Hope you are enjoying the album!!! The campaign for the release party (Late May for strategical reasons) is under way!
So which songs are your favorites?? What do you like best??? What do you want to see performed?!?!?

Hello my dear backers! I'm back in the studio recording some new tracks and re-recording some old ones, making everything sound SPECTACULAR. Yesterday I got to a new song, with lyrics written by Mariana Poblete of Cordoba, Argentina...and it's turning out really cool. The music is very Bolivian inspired...big drums, deep pan-flutes, choruses of Quenas. 
As a little update on how the music actually SOUNDS, I'll be posting some clips here for you guys to check out. This one is from what is planned to be the second-to-last song, right now temporarily titled "Final". It's about (ha, there are no lyrics) summing everything of a grand adventure up, reliving it for a moment, and saying goodbye to it. Coming back to your proper reality. And not just goodbye, but it and , and then not wanting to look away from it. The songs is cognizant of the fact that the smile starts to turn hard in the end...hard to maintain because you're suddenly filled with such deep questions at the idea of something so large being...over. I guess you could say it's almost a "celebration of death"...just more metaphorically, haha. (Named the post title after writing this)

Hey backers! Recently I've been in El Paso, TX for a few weeks doing some freelance work and to see a friend finally tie the knot! Wedding this weekend! 
I go back to Memphis on Monday, at which point I will immediately begin arranging the final pieces of the album. There are about three unrecorded songs, all of which have strengthened themselves as ideas while I've been away. Ha, it actually helps a lot to step back, stop trying, and let things come. And they have.

Dios mio!!! This is amazing. You guys really made this possible to an extent that I don't yet fully grasp or understand. I can't WAIT to get this album in your hands for you to listen.
Thanks to all of you, the album will SOUND better, LOOK better...it will be BE better. In fact, it will BE. I can't thank you all enough. You're all participating in something really special - a breaking of borders between cultures and the celebration of music! Nothing brings people together better, and to do such a crazy cross-cultural experiment has been a lot of fun.

And, there is good news! I have been breaking from mixing and back to writing, and there might be an extra song or two than I thought there would be before! So it looks like we are between 12-14 tracks right now! I want to give a margin of error in case one or two get cut...gotta keep only the REALLY GOOD STUFF!!!

campaign.story:
A multi-purpose kitchen tool designed to mix, fold, sauté, and stir foods at any temperature.
We're out to create the perfect spatula. A spatula made from a single piece of silicone, heat resistant to 464°F, with weight and balance that make it easy to whip up a quick batch of pancakes, and fun to stir your grandma's spaghetti sauce for six hours on a Sunday afternoon. Nothing fancy here. No gimmicks. Just the best spatula you've ever used.
THANK YOU FOR AN AMAZING CAMPAIGN!
This was a lot of fun - thanks for the support. We're wrapping up on Kickstarter, but the GIR Spatula is here to stay! Visit our website at productofgir.com to get your hands on the Spatula and keep track of the latest from GIR.
THE STORY BEHIND IT ALL
It started with a common spatula… or more accurately, with a drawer of spatulas. For a tool that's so simple it's nearly two-dimensional, but integral to any cook's toolkit, we felt let down by every model we put in our hands.
Wooden handles burned on the edge of the pan and warped in the dishwasher. Metal handles were hot to the touch. Detachable blades and superfluous nooks and crannies trapped oil and food particles, which made cleaning a chore. Some were floppy, others so inflexible they couldn't scrape a bowl. And anything but a silicone blade had us worried that we'd ruin nonstick pans or be eating plastic out of the skillet if we turned around for more than a few seconds. Out of a collection of over a dozen, not a single one "got it right."
We figured it was time for a change. So we designed a spatula that solved every one of those problems. Our small improvements to otherwise run-of-the-mill utensils have added up to an innovative, multi-purpose kitchen tool. And after several months of testing and prototype design, we're ready to rock and happy to introduce the patent-pending GIR Spatula: a single piece of molded silicone, heat resistant to 464°, easy to clean and easy to hold, flex- vs. structure-optimized.
CORE DESIGN HIGHLIGHTS & KEY BENEFITS
SAFE & HEAT RESISTANT
The Spatula does not get hot to the touch and it does not melt or burn: its heat resistant silicone withstands temperatures to 464°F (and you can deep freeze it to -40°F if you're in the mood).
AN INCREDIBLY VERSATILE KITCHEN TOOL
The heavy-duty silicone rubber and strong but flexible blade make it easy to maneuver food, liquid, dry mixes, wet batters... you name it. Suitable for containers of all sizes: bowls, pots, hot pans, and plates.
FOR HOME & PROFESSIONAL USE
We like to think of the Spatula as the ultimate kitchen tool, friendly and approachable enough for beginners at home, as well as super sanitary and multipurpose enough to serve as the go-to tool for experienced chefs at work. Lightweight but sturdy, non-slippery with a comfortable handle and grip, the Spatula was designed with both the occasional cook and seasoned chef in mind.
CLEANS THOROUGHLY & EASILY
The Spatula’s solid body construction doesn't trap food or oil particulates. It's quick and easy to clean by hand, so you can get right back to cooking. And of course, it's dishwasher safe. We put it through hundreds of cycles to make sure it didn't degrade or wear over time. And it performed just beautifully.
ECO-FRIENDLY & LONG-LASTING
Made of eco-friendly, non-toxic material, the Spatula is designed to spend a lifetime in your kitchen.
PATENT PENDING
The Spatula's novel design and construction make it a one-of-a-kind kitchen implement. So we can add another cool item to its highlight reel: Patent Pending.
WITH YOUR SUPPORT
We've come a long way. The Spatula graduated from idea to prototype, and now it's ready for the big time. We're gearing up to launch a full-scale manufacturing run, and we can't do it without your help.
So where are we now? We've:
- Finalized the Spatula's design, from handle to blade
- Tested a range of material combinations
- Built and tested five generations of silicone prototypes
- Tested a production run of units in every color
By supporting this effort, you'll be the first to get your hands on a game-changing spatula unlike any other.
We're on track to deliver the first batch to our Kickstarter backers by early December 2012. We think they belong in every kitchen in the world, starting with yours.
WHAT WILL YOURS LOOK LIKE?
We bet you have a drawer or bucket of subpar (or uninspiring) spatulas just like we did. If we may be so bold: throw them all away, and get the Ultimate Spatula. We wouldn't blame you if your next purchase was a trophy case.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We spent the better part of a year designing, developing, prototyping, testing, and beating up the GIR Spatula. If we were going to claim it as the "ultimate," it HAD to stand up to the wear and tear of daily use… as well as some more extreme treatment.

Here were some of the biggest challenges:
• Refining the design of the polymer core so that we'd hit the optimal flex level
• Selecting the appropriate food-grade silicone to use 
• Running test batches of silicone in each Pantone color until they looked right
• Testing each color's durability with 7+ hours in simmering tomato sauce 
• Finding a manufacturer willing to work with us to produce smaller prototype orders so that we could get our models in the kitchen and test them (and test them, and test them…) 
• Destroying almost every other spatula we owned to uncover any weaknesses we'd overlooked (RIP, stainless steel pan with melted plastic spatula all over it)

What we came up with was unique enough to merit an application to the USPTO. So our intrepid little spatula is Patent Pending.

We're really proud of the amount of design, brainpower, and cooking that have gone into this project. We've put up some real investment dollars of our own to get it to this stage, and nothing would be a better reward than seeing you (and your friends) try it out for yourselves. Who knows - it could be love at first sight.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The bulk of the challenge has been met ... but the risk still remains. The minimum money order for professionally printed playing cards is $6,250. If the project is funded, I have been guaranteed by the printing company that the shipment of all decks will be delivered to me by early December. I will then work like a horse to package, number and ship every individuals order so that they will have their decks before by December 18th. Just in time for you to wrap them up and put a nice bow on them for Christmas.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Playing Cards — Pay What You Can
updates.update_content: Hello everyone — You are the group that started it all for me and I wanted to let you know that we’re offering a new pay-what-you-can option for our most essential goods. My hope is that this offer can help ease some of the strain so many of us are feeling. This deal includes our playing cards along with most of our smell good products. Learn more...

updates.update_userinfo: Updates! Shirts Re-Print and Bundle Deals.
updates.update_content:
Hey Everyone! 
It's been almost 6 years since you all first helped me launch Misc. Goods Co.! I still stand in awe of that experience. I hope the playing cards have served you well and helped create new memories with your family and friends. 
I wanted to give three quick updates:

updates.update_userinfo: Exclusive Preview of New Site + 30% Discount
A gift, thank you and update.
updates.update_content:
Hello Everyone, Starting this year I’m offering an annual discount on our entire store to all of my original supporters (you all) every January. The business is growing and I’m developing 12 new products this year alone. Sometimes I randomly consider where I am and still wonder at how it all happened … and I’m overcome with thankfulness for you all.
The discount for this January is 40% off of entire store with the discount code: MGCO-Starters

updates.update_userinfo: Closing Thoughts, A Time Lapse Video, New Products, Etc.
updates.update_content:
Hello Everyone,
I am writing to share some closing thoughts.
First ... a lot of you were wondering what it looked like for a no-nothing like myself to turn his humble office into a full-on fulfillment company. To capture this event as best as I could, I had my friend Justin Gustavinson take the time to setup several time lapse cameras throughout the office during the 12 day shipping frenzy that we endured in the month of December. Check it out below.

Hey Everyone,
I hope your holidays were restful and encouraging.
If you filled out your order survey before Nov. 13th ... Then your package has been sent out. If it hasn't arrived yet, please give it another week or so. If you filled it out after the 13th, I will be fulfilling your order in January.

Hey Everyone,
Staying busy over here and having loads of fun. It's good for me to pull away from the computer screen and start getting my hands on rulers, boxes, tape and scales. All in preparation for the big packing days ahead of me. I have also been forced to work out my math skills lately. My 10th grade calculus teacher Mrs. Neff would be proud.
If you have already completed your order survey, live in the US or already covered your international shipping fees ... Thank you, but the rest of this update does not apply to you.

updates.update_userinfo: Under Two Hours, Uncut Sheets, Etc.
updates.update_content:
YOU GUYS ARE THE BEST!
And just to be clear, I try to avoid all caps at all costs. But there was no other solution for the above expression. So flattered by all of the response, support and encouragement that has consistently prevailed during this whole project.
Uncut sheets: 3 uncut sheets were opened up in the last tier. If any of you are interested.

Hello to all of my supporters outside of the U.S.
I am amazed by your interest. You can probably tell by my project structure, that I had no idea that I would receive so much diverse interest. I am thrilled to be receiving orders from Asia, Europe, Latin America and so many other amazing parts of the world that I wish to one day visit. It is so great how the internet allows us to experience community with each other, although we live so far away.

I decided to give one deck to my brother-in-law so I opened the package today after all and wore my fantastic Ace of Clubs t-shirt this evening. Very pleased with the look. We had a pre-school graduation for my nearly five year old. So far so pleasant. Afterwards we walked 10 minutes to a cafe for fish and chips where I looked across at my wife and saw a hole in the setting of her engagement ring where there used to be a diamond. Disaster! I retraced our steps back to the pre-school, scouring the pavement all the way. No joy. Back in the pre-school with plenty of kids running around at full tilt I returned to the main spot where we had been standing and after searching hard with much joy retrieved the diamond nestled in a crack in the ground. So I reckon the Ace of Clubs t-shirt is indeed lucky. I still can't quite believe I actually found it. Thanks for a great deck and for bringing good luck.

campaign.story:
Flint and Tinder is ...
1. Highest quality ingredients for SUPERIOR COMFORT and DURABILITY
2. 100% Made in America - SUPPORTS USA ECONOMY
3. Fairly priced
... help support by making this your next pair of underwear today.


Hey Kickstarter,
Thanks for checking out my project.

It’s been a wild ride, starting with my noticing that all of the underwear currently on sale at major department stores comes from other countries… and the vast majority is made with poor materials.

Before I knew it – and without much prior-knowledge – I was trying to find a US factory to make the superior product I had in mind. So far, so good. 
I've got the designs, sourced the fabrics and findings, and found a factory that needs this product as much as I need them... I just need $30,000 to get it going. 
Please support at whatever level you're comfortable with. We'll pay you back with some really fantastic underwear, crafted for comfort with super-high quality materials you’re going to love. If you’ve got the time though, be sure to read the info below as well, it’s wordy but worth it.
Ready for the best bit? Beyond this opening order, for every 1000 pair we sell per month, 1 full-time job is literally added back to the assembly line. Amazing, right?
Thanks for your support. - Jake
AND NOW, A LAST MINUTE EDITION: We've added shirts to our line.
You asked for it, you got it! Flint and Tinder 100% Supima cotton, double soft-washed, Tagless Tees in two great styles: V-Neck and Crew Neck. Comparable shirts retail from $45 to $85, and go up from there. PLEASE NOTE: Shirts only come in white at this time. They're coming in the same S, M, L, XL, and XXL as the undies (even larger sizes to follow soon after our proper launch).
A few questions you're likely to ask... 
What makes this underwear better than the other stuff out there? 
We started with the highest quality materials for an unbelievable level of comfort, then spared no expense making sure the construction was built to last.
The goal is that, from the minute you first put them on through a lifetime of washing, you can feel the difference. That they were made in America should be the icing on the cake.
PIMA cotton vs SUPIMA cotton; What’s the difference there? 
PIMA cotton is some of the finest cotton on earth. It has extremely long, silky fibers that when properly spun produce a breathable, soft yet durable yarn. But garments labeled PIMA are known to have as little as 5% PIMA, with the remainder of the fibers coming from lesser, easier to produce cotton strains.
SUPIMA is a trademarked term referring only to American gown PIMA cotton. Using this term requires a license in which the governing body, which closely monitors and licenses every step of the process, certifies that 100% of the cotton used is SUPIMA.
Flint and Tinder only uses SUPIMA cotton.
Lets talk design... 
Yes, lets. We started by incorporating every feature you’d find on the most expensive pairs of underwear. With each prototype, we stripped away a little bit more, until we were left with a perfectly balanced garment; Simple in design, rugged in construction, refined in our selection of top-notch materials.
Where does the underwear I’m wearing right now come from? 
Hard to say without looking at your tag (even a single brand often manufactures in several different countries). Of the underwear available on shelves in Manhattan, here’s what some of their tags say:
2(x)Ist — Thailand
A/X — Peru
Adidas — Indonesia
American Eagle Outfitters — Macao
Banana Republic — Indonesia
Boss Orange — Egypt
Brooks Brothers — Thailand
BVD — El Salvador
Calvin Klein — Vietnam
Clayborne — Pakistan
David Beckham/H&M — Cambodia
Diesel — China
Emporio Armani — Thailand
Fruit of the Loom — Vietnam
Gap — Indonesia
Hanes — India
Hugo Boss — China
Izod — China
J. Crew — China
Jockey — India
Joe Boxer — China
Kenneth Cole — Thailand
Old Navy — India
Pact — Turkey
Polo / Ralph Lauren — El Salvador
Stafford — Thailand
Tommy Hilfiger — Indonesia
Under Armor — Cambodia
Uniqulo — China
Wrangler — China
etc. etc. etc. Only one comes from the US– American Apparel, but it's not hugely comfortable, isn't made of premium materials, and falls apart in the dryer over time.
Will buying Flint and Tinder create American jobs? 
You bet your ass it will! And not in some vague way either…
The factory I'm working with is family owned and operated. It’s over 100 years old. Just before the recession hit, they moved into a larger facility and invested in some of the capital improvements shown in the video (solar power etc.).
At that time they had 300+ employees and were hoping to double or triple in size. When we started this project however, with the economy in free-fall, they were down to just 90.
They’ve agreed to learn to make this new, high-end brand of American-made underwear. Here’s the fun part though: For every 1000 pair we sell per month, 1 full-time job has to be added back to the assembly line. Hopefully, with your support, it will help them keep the doors open.
Wait, how can you make a product here in the US (where labor costs are higher), using better materials, and still charge a competitive price?
Great question. It’s hard, but not impossible.
1—Flint and Tinder will sell direct to consumers through our own website. This will avoid the 100% mark-up most stores add to products.
 2—The next stop is wholesale, but with almost no mark-up on our end, making the final retail price about the same as what we sell them for online. Why would we sell our product in a way that lets stores profit while hardly making anything on the deal ourselves? Simple: It’s going to allow us to create an American alternative that sits on shelves right next to it’s foreign-born competitors at a competitive price. Doing this supports our manufacturing partners (as they’ll get to make more underwear), but it’s also good marketing since many customers  like touching products in a retail environment that they later order from the web (meaning we’ll get to sell more underwear online too).

There's always changes to be made in a business, Jake. I understand that. You strive for perfection. But Kickstarter provides you with something (well, other than funding) that is not easy to get anywhere else for free -- a gigantic focus group. I see you indicated you'll be sending out a feedback survey, which is great, but I just wish that we had either been presented with a final set of design options to vote on, or at least been asked our opinion of the final design comparative to the original before production began. I hope that in your survey you will ask to gauge backers' interest in buying F&T undies that keep the high-contrast stitching that this project pitched to us. Who knows, maybe I'm the only guy out of 5,578 that even noticed or thinks it looks better. But I doubt it. If that's what most of us pledged for, I don't see why F&T shouldn't at least offer both styles. For now I think I'll look into returning at least the white trunks (still unopened), as I can tolerate the color ones that have at least some fabric contrast, but I simply can't do blank-white ... it needs that black stitching, especially on those side seams. Anyway, I'll get off my soapbox now and wait for the survey to come in. Regardless of whether you retain my personal business going forward, I hope Flint & Tinder becomes incredibly successful and helps reignite American-made products. Thanks for supporting the American worker, Jake. And thanks for listening.

I really enjoy them so far, and would consider buying more in the future, but likely only if you put that high-contrast stitching back in. At the price it takes to buy these, I'd at least want my undies to stand out and look different than other undies, and it's the contrast stitching that really made them pop (as it stands, my white boxer briefs look like any other generic boxer brief ... I would never have chosen white if I knew this beforehand). Look, I don't mean to be overly negative -- you've done an excellent thing with F&T, Jake, and overall I think the underwear will do a great job replacing my cheap foreign-made wardrobe in fit, comfort, and longevity -- but you took a huge hit in the aesthetics department. They may be hidden under my pants the majority of the time, but looks are still a major factor for me when choosing underwear.

American made boxers and jockeys!!! When I backed this project for $125, I knew there was a risk involved. The Judi machines might have come through, whatever licenses they need or materials might not come through. Kickstarter is nt about investing. It is about giving someone some money to possibly get something in exchange and to get the excitement of being part of someone else's idea and project which might grow. All that being said, I do want my underwear. I just threw out some old, worn frayed boxers. I also want to see photos of the Judi laser cutting machine and of the manufacturing space. This is a cool project and I would like to see how it develops. As far as the kvetchers and complainers who will never give money for another Kickstarter project, what's the matter? This all is not a purchase. It is a fun gamble on someone else's dream. If there was no risk, there would be no excitement. Also, that weird survey ordering bug was not such a big problem. Jake: I appreciate the response. I was a little reactive because for once the sizing originally listed had me squarely in the middle of a range, so it felt like for the first time in my adult life I might have underwear that was meant to fit me, rather than always having to deal with briefs that were either too confining or too baggy. In most cases, small fits me best in the waist and butt, but is way too tight in the crotch, while medium is less constrictive in front but tends to be too baggy in the rear and thighs (OK, TMI). In the end, though, your final sizing chart with a one-inch gap between sizes isn't much different that what I'm used to, and in fact is better than the two-inch gap some lines use. So the good of what you're doing outweighs my still not finding that elusive perfect fit. And my husband certainly won't mind if I end up having to give them to him.

I'm very disappointed that the sizing changed post-funding. One of the reasons I was enthusiastic was that the original sizing met my needs better than existing underwear lines, which leave one to two-inch gaps between sizes. As someone who has a 31.5 inch waist, it's now not clear what size I should order, since small tops out at 31 and medium begins at 32. Changing such a vital piece of information is a poor way to start out your business, especially with those of us funding you up-front. I'll order the small, and if they don't fit I'll give them to my partner, but it leaves a bad taste in my mouth.

I just got the order form... None of your sizes are even close to fitting me. I have a 48" Waist and a 56" chest, and am 6'7" tall, so I'd need a long. Not sure what to do. Generally XXL boxers fit me just fine, but this sizing seems off.
Are the boxer brief sizes accurate to the waist measurements listed? A lot of them run big.
How about an option to send half the order on the deadline and the other half at another time. This would incur extra shipping charges but lets you maybe work around your volume problem.
Hey Kyle--he said that he would have color samples after the whole thing was over, so those will probably be coming soon.

Just wanted to reiterate my request for actual color samples before we have to choose. congratulations - almost $300k pledged total, a huge leap from your original asking amount. Really hope to see more from you guys in the future, and as long as the product is solid (which I trust it will be) you'll definitely have a for life buyer.

Congratulations Jake on making almost 10 times what you set out to accomplish! It feels good to know we'll all have a hand in putting some Americans back to work with this Kickstarter, and reap the benefits of some quality undergarments while we're at it!

Hey Jake, I noticed in the product lineup pic on the front page, the new longer trunks don't appear to have the same stylish seam as the short trunks. Is that the case with all colors of the longer trunks, or just white, or ... ?
